DT Article
TI A new genus of soft coral of the family Alcyoniidae (Cnidaria,
   Octocorallia) with re-description of a new combination and description
   of a new species.
AU Benayahu, Yehuda (yehudab@tauex.tau.ac.il) 
   McFadden, Catherine S.
SO ZooKeys
VL 84
PS 1-11
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=504a1dae70c26c22886b0e3a0385eb9d&issue_id=108
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/781/abstract/a-new-genus
   -of-soft-coral-of-the-family-alcyoniidae-cnidaria-octocorallia-with-re-d
   escription-of-a-new-combination-and-d
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus, Aldersladum (family Alcyoniidae), is established to
   accommodate a previously described species, Efflatounaria sodwanae
   Benayahu, 1993 (family Xeniidae) from Sodwana Bay, South Africa that was
   wrongly assigned to the latter genus. This species is redescribed and a
   second new species, A. jengi from Penghu Is., Taiwan, is described. The
   diagnostic features of the new genus include the presence of only
   figure-eight shaped platelets in all parts of the colony, thus
   differentiating it from all known genera of the Alcyoniidae. Based on
   examination of additional material from other localities, the
   zoogeographical distribution of the genus is confirmed to include the
   coral reefs of South Africa, Kenya, Gulf of Oman, Taiwan and Japan.
   Phylogenetic analyses of two mitochondrial genes strongly support its
   placement in the family Alcyoniidae.
C1 Benayahu, Yehuda; Department of Zoology, George S. Wise Faculty of Life
   Sciences, Tel Aviv University, Ramat Aviv, Tel Aviv 69978, Israel,
   Israel.
EM yehudab@tauex.tau.ac.il
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Aldersladum jengi [North Pacific / Japan / New species] [ / Taiwan / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Octocorallia
OR Aldersladum (Octocorallia): [Gen nov, Of family Alcyoniidae, Type
   species Efflatounaria sodwanae Benayahu 1993, p. 3]. 
   Aldersladum jengi (Octocorallia): [Sp nov, Taiwan (marine), P. 5]. 
   Aldersladum sodwanum - (Benayahu 1993) (Octocorallia): [Redescription,
   P. 5; Comb nov, Transferred from Efflatounaria, p. 3]. 
   Efflatounaria sodwanae - Benayahu 1993 (Octocorallia): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Aldersladum, p. 3]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14705036687

TI Notes on the Nazeris fauna of Yunnan Province, China (Coleoptera,
   Staphylinidae, Paederinae).

   Zhao, Yun-long (ylzhao@bio.ecnu.edu.cn)

   he-nazeris-fauna-of-yunnan-province-china-coleoptera-staphylinidae-paede

LA English
U1 1
U2 1

   nabanhensis sp. n. and N. caoi sp. n. The male sexual characters are
   described and illustrated. A key to the Nazeris species of Yunnan is
   provided. A map of the collecting sites is given.

TI Revision of the South American window fly genus Heteromphrale Kroeber,
   1937 (Diptera, Scenopinidae).
AU Winterton, Shaun L. (wintertonshaun@gmail.com) 
   Gaimari, Stephen D.
SO ZooKeys
VL 84
PS 39-57
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=504a1dae70c26c22886b0e3a0385eb9d&issue_id=108
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/774/abstract/revision-of
   -the-south-american-window-fly-genus-heteromphrale-kr
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The Neotropical window fly genus Heteromphrale Kroeber, 1937 is revised.
   Two previously described species (H. chilensis (Kroeber, 1937) and H.
   cyanops (Edwards, 1932)) are redescribed while a new species (H. blanca
   sp. n.) is described from Argentina. The male of H. chilensis and female
   of H. cyanops are described and figured for the first time, and a key to
   species is presented.

   Scenopinidae

   (Diptera, Muscidae): revised key, synonymy and notes on ecology.
AU Vikhrev, Nikita (nikita6510@ya.ru) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 84
PS 59-70
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=504a1dae70c26c22886b0e3a0385eb9d&issue_id=108
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/819/review-of-the-palaea
   rctic-members-of-the-lispe-tentaculata-species-group-diptera-muscidae-re
   vised-key-synonymy-and-notes
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The taxonomic reasons for regarding Lispe draperi Seguy, 1933, sp. rev.,
   as a valid species instead of a synonym of Lispe tentaculata (De Geer,
   1776) and for treating Lispe quaerens Villeneuve, 1936, syn. n., as a
   junior synonym of Lispe sericipalpis Stein, 1904 are given. A revised
   key for the Palaearctic members of the Lispe tentaculata species-group
   is given. Data on ecology, distribution and feeding preferences are
   provided.

DT Article
TI Taxonomy and biology of two seed-parasitic gracillariid moths
   (Lepidoptera, Gracillariidae), with description of a new species.
AU Hu, Bingbing
   Wang, Shuxia
   Zhang, Jing
   Li, Houhun (lihouhun@nankai.edu.cn) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 83
PS 43-56
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=5d2641496eedbe7138b4a37a0b4bc322&issue_id=107
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/783/taxonomy-and-biology
   -of-two-seed-parasitic-gracillariid-moths-lepidoptera-gracillariidae-wit
   h-description-of-one-new-spe
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new species and new record of gracillariid moths from China are
   reported: Conopomorpha flueggella Li, sp. n. and Epicephala relictella
   Kuznetzov, 1979. Specimens were collected on flowers or leaves of
   Flueggea suffruticosa (Pall.) Baill. (Euphorbiaceae) at night, and
   reared from fruits in captivity. Larvae of both species feed on the
   seeds of F. suffruticosa, but they can be differentiated externally by
   the position of the red pattern on the thorax and abdomen. Morphology of
   the eggs, larvae, pupae and the life history of the two species are
   described and compared. Images of the life history and figures of the
   genital structures are provided.
C1 Li, Houhun; College of Life Sciences, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071,
   China, China.
EM lihouhun@nankai.edu.cn
SC Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics
SN 1313-2970

   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Conopomorpha flueggella [Tianjin /  / New species]. 
   Epicephala relictella [Food plants / Flueggea suffruticosa / New record;
   systematics] [China /  / ] [Tianjin / Baxian Mountain State Nature
   Reserves / biology]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Tineoidea, Gracillariidae

   46].

TI Three new species of the leafhopper genus Tautoneura Anufriev
   (Hemiptera, Cicadellidae, Typhlocybinae) from China.
AU Song, Yuehua
   Li, Zizhong
   Xiong, Kangning (xiongkn@163.com) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 83
PS 63-72
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=5d2641496eedbe7138b4a37a0b4bc322&issue_id=107
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/1178/three-new-species-o
   f-the-leafhopper-genus-tautoneura-anufriev-hemiptera-cicadellidae-typhlo
   cybinae-from-china
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The leafhopper genus Tautoneura Anufriev (1969) belongs to the tribe
   Erythroneurini (Typhlocybinae) with Tautoneura tricolor Anufriev, 1969
   as its type species. The genus consists of fifty-one species distributed
   in the Oriental and Palaearctic Regions. So far, twelve species in
   Tautoneura have been reported from China. A key to Chinese species and a
   species checklist of Tautoneura from China are provided. In this paper,
   three new species are described and illustrated from Henan, Yunnan and
   Gangsu Provinces of China. All specimens examined are deposited to the
   Institute of South China Karst, Guizhou Normal University (ISCK) and
   Insititute of Entomology, Guizhou University (IEGU), Guiyang, China.
C1 Xiong, Kangning; Institute of South China Karst, Guizhou Normal

   Tautoneura baiyunshana [Henan /  / New species]. 
   Tautoneura caoi [Gansu /  / New species].

TI A synopsis of east-Mediterranean Synaphris Simon, 1894 (Araneae,
   Synaphridae) with a description of a new species from Israel.
AU Marusik, Yuri M.
   Zonstein, Sergei (znn@post.tau.ac.il) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 82
PS 35-44
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=auzykddds&issue_id=106
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/957/abstract/a-synopsis-
   of-east-mediterranean-synaphris-simon-1894-araneae-synaphridae-with-a-de
   scription-of-a-new-species-from-israe
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Three species of Synaphris occurring in the East Mediterranean - S.
   orientalis Marusik & Lehtinen, 2003, S. lehtineni Marusik, Gnelitsa &
   Kovblyuk, 2005 and S. letourneuxi (Simon, 1884) - are surveyed; and a
   new species - S. wunderlichi sp. n. - is described from southern Israel
   on the basis of males. The new species differs from other
   East-Mediterranean congeners by its smaller size, a smaller lamella with
   fewer ridges, and a thick palpal femur. Comparative figures are provided
   for all species from the East Mediterranean

DT Article
TI Coulmannia rossensis sp. n. (Isopoda, Asellota, Paramunnidae) from the
   Ross Sea, Southern Ocean.
AU Choudhury, Madhumita (bdoti@bg.fcen.uba.ar) 
   Doti, Brenda
   Brandt, Angelika
SO ZooKeys
VL 82
PS 45-57
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=auzykddds&issue_id=106
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/775/abstract/coulmannia-
   rossensis-sp-n-isopoda-asellota-paramunnidae-from-the-ross-sea-southern-
   ocean
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of Coulmannia, C. rossensis, is described from the Ross
   Sea, Antarctica. It is most similar to C. ramosae Castell, 2004, but can
   easily be distinguished from this species by the males yielding a pair
   of granulate humps on the dorsum of the pereonites 1-6 and a single
   granulate hump on the pereonite 7 and the free pleonite. Coulmannia
   rossensis sp. n. is sexually dimorphic. The dorsal sculpture of the
   female bodies yield a single granulate hump on all the pereonites and
   free pleonite. The species of the genus Coulmannia are restricted to the
   Southern Ocean, and C. rossensis sp. n. is the fourth species included
   in it.
C1 Choudhury, Madhumita; Zoological Institute and Museum, University of
   Hamburg, Martin-Luther-King-Platz 3, 20146 Hamburg, Germany, Germany.
EM bdoti@bg.fcen.uba.ar
RI Brandt, Angelika/C-1630-2018
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Marine
   zones
DE Coulmannia [Marine zones / Southern Ocean / Distribution; systematics]. 
   Coulmannia rossensis [Antarctic Ocean / Antarctica / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Isopoda
OR Coulmannia - Hodgson 1910 (Isopoda): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, Species, p. 55; Key to species, P. 47]. 
   Coulmannia rossensis (Isopoda): [Sp nov, Antarctica (marine), P. 47].

   Shi, Baojun
   Wu, Dayong
   Zhou, Wenjie
SO ZooKeys
VL 82
PS 59-66
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=auzykddds&issue_id=106
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/823/abstract/a-new-speci
   es-of-lithobius-monotarsobius-verhoeff-1905-lithobiomorpha-lithobiidae-f
   rom-china
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The present paper deals with a new species of the genus Lithobius Leach,
   1814, L. (Monotarsobius) songi sp. n. (Lithobiomorpha: Lithobiidae)
   recently discovered in Hebei Province, China. Morphologically it
   resembles L. (M.) holstii (Pocock, 1895) from China and Japan but could
   be well distinguished from latter bya Tomosvary's organ slightly smaller
   than the adjoining ocelli, different leg plectrotaxy and tridentate claw
   of female gonopods. A key to the Chinese Lithobius (Monotarsobius)
   species is presented.

TI First record of the genus Aprivesa Melichar (Hemiptera, Fulgoromorpha)
   from South India, with description of one new species.
AU Bu, Cui-Ping
   Liang, Ai-Ping (liangap@ioz.ac.cn) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 81
PS 1-12
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=auzykddds&issue_id=105
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/816/abstract/first-recor
   d-of-the-genus-aprivesa-melichar-hemiptera-fulgoromorpha-from-south-indi
   a-with-description-of-one-new-species
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Aprivesa unimaculata sp. n. (Hemiptera: Fulgoromorpha: Ricaniidae) is
   described and illustrated from Coorg, south India. This represents the
   first record of the genus Aprivesa Melichar from India and the fourth
   known species of Aprivesa. The new taxon greatly extends the range of
   the genus Aprivesa, which was previously known as an endemic Australian
   genus. A checklist of all known species of the Ricaniidae from India and
   keys to all the known genera of the Ricaniidae from India and all
   species in the genus are provided.
C1 Liang, Ai-Ping; Key Laboratory of Zoological Systematics and Evolution,

   Chaoyang District, Beijing 100101, China, China.

   Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia;

TI The first Strigocis Dury (Coleoptera, Ciidae) from the southern
   Neotropical region and a provisional key to world species.
AU Lopez-Andrade, Cristiano (ciidae@gmail.com) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 81
PS 27-37
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=auzykddds&issue_id=105
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/940/abstract/the-first-s
   trigocis-dury-coleoptera-ciidae-from-the-southern-neotropical-region-and
   -a-provisional-key-to-world-species
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Strigocis vicosensis Lopes-Andrade, sp. n. is described based on
   specimens from a single locality (type locality: Vicosa, state of Minas
   Gerais, southeastern Brazil), being the southernmost record of a
   Strigocis Dury species. Diagnostic to this new species are the dorsal
   vestiture consisting of stout yellowish bristles, pronotal punctures
   separated from each other by at least 0.75 x puncture-width and sutural
   l ange of elytra not diverging near apex. Males have both frontoclypeal
   ridge and anterior pronotal margin produced forward and emarginated at
   middle forming two small subtriangular plates, and a small abdominal sex
   patch. Among the New World Strigocis, it most resembles S. bilimeki
   (Reitter), of which images of male terminalia, as far as ventral and
   dorsal SEM images of males are also provided. The morphological limits
   of Strigocis are briefly discussed and redefined, and a provisional key
   to the world species is provided.
C1 Lopez-Andrade, Cristiano; Departamento de Biologia Animal, Universidade
   Federal de Vicosa, 36570-000, Vicosa, Minas Gerais, Brazil, Brazil.
EM ciidae@gmail.com

OI Lopes-Andrade, Cristiano/0000-0001-9652-1369

   zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Strigocis [Neotropical region / South / New record].

TI Review of the genus Fibuloides Kuznetsov in China (Lepidoptera,
   Tortricidae, Olethreutinae).
AU Zhang, Aihuan
   Li, Houhun (lihouhun@nankai.edu.cn) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 81
PS 39-50
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=auzykddds&issue_id=105
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/833/abstract/review-of-t
   he-genus-fibuloides-kuznetsov-lepidoptera-tortricidae-olethreutinae-in-c
   hina
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Species of the genus Fibuloides Kuznetsov that occur in China are
   reviewed. Fibuloides trapezoidea, sp. n. is described as new; F.
   levatana (Kuznetsov) and F. modificana Kuznetsov are newly recorded for
   China; Acroclita nigrovenana Kuznetsov, syn. n. is considered as a
   synonym of F. corinthia (Meyrick); and Eucoenogenes elongata Zhang & Li
   and E. wuyiensis Zhang & Li are transferred to Fibuloides, resulting in
   two new combinations. A key to the nine Chinese species of Fibuloides is
   given.

DT Article
TI A new Gephyromantis (Phylacomantis) frog species from the pinnacle karst
   of Bemaraha, western Madagascar.
AU Crottini, Angelica
   Glaw, Frank
   Casiraghi, Maurizio
   Jenkins, Richard
   Mercurio, Vincenzo
   Randrianantoandro, Christian
   Randrianirina, Jasmin
   Andreone, Franco (franco.andreone@regione.piemonte.it) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 81
PS 51-71
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=auzykddds&issue_id=105
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/1111/abstract/a-new-geph
   yromantis-phylacomantis-frog-species-from-the-pinnacle-karst-of-bemaraha
   -western-madagascar
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We describe a new mantellid frog of the subfamily Mantellinae from the
   karstic Bemaraha Plateau, western Madagascar. The new species belongs to
   the genus Gephyromantis, subgenus Phylacomantis, which previously
   included G. azzurrae, G. corvus and G. pseudoasper. Gephyromantis
   atsingy sp. n. has a snout-vent length of 35-43 mm and is a scansorial
   frog living among the Tsingy de Bemaraha pinnacles and inside the caves
   present in the area. A morphological analysis and biomolecular
   comparison revealed the degree of differentiation between these four
   species of the Phylacomantis subgenus. The new species seems to be
   endemic to Tsingy de Bemaraha.
C1 Andreone, Franco; Museo Regionale di Scienze Naturali, Via G. Giolitti
   36, 10123 Torino, Italy, Italy.
EM franco.andreone@regione.piemonte.it
RI Crottini, Angelica/I-7680-2013; ANDREONE, FRANCO/H-4942-2012; Casiraghi,
   Maurizio/E-7273-2011
OI Crottini, Angelica/0000-0002-8505-3050; ANDREONE,
   FRANCO/0000-0001-9809-5818; Casiraghi, Maurizio/0000-0002-2733-2094
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region; Africa

   subordinate taxa, P. 66].

   Platygastridae) are revised: 42 species are recognized, of which two

   n.; T. carinata Talamas, sp. n.; T. cincta Talamas & Masner, sp. n.; T.

TI A simultaneous journal / wiki publication and dissemination of a new
   species description: Neobidessodes darwiniensis sp. n. from northern
   Australia (Coleoptera, Dytiscidae, Bidessini).
AU Henrich, Lars (hendrich@zsm.mwn.de) 
   Balke, Michael
SO ZooKeys
VL 79
PS 11-20
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=453a553a48a53cb80d40f8d16c8816ee&issue_id=99
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/803/a-simultaneous-journ
   al-wiki-publication-and-dissemination-of-a-new-species-description-neobi
   dessodes-darwiniensis-sp-n-f
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Here, we describe a new Australian species in journal format and
   simultaneously open the description in a wiki format on the
   www.species-id.net. The wiki format will always link to the fixed
   original journal description of the taxon, however it permits future
   edits and additions to species' taxonomy and biology. The diving beetle
   Neobidessodes darwiniensis sp. n. (Coleoptera: Dytiscidae, Bidessini) is
   described based on a single female, collected in a rest pool of the
   Harriet Creek in the Darwin Area, Northern Territory. Within
   Neobidessodes the new species is well characterized by its elongate oval
   body with rounded sides, short and stout segments of antennae, length of
   body and dorsal surface coloration. In addition to external morphology,
   we used mitochondrial cox1 sequence data to support generic assignment
   and to delineate the new species from other Australian Bidessini
   including all other known Neobidessodes. Illustrations based on digital
   images are provided here and as online resources. A modified key is
   provided. Altogether ten species of the genus are now known worldwide,
   nine from Australia and one from New Guinea.
C1 Henrich, Lars; Zoologische Staatssammlung, Muenchhausenstrasse 21,
   D-81247 Muenchen, Germany, Germany.
EM hendrich@zsm.mwn.de
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Documentation;
   Publications; Land zones; Australasian region; Oriental region; Eurasia;
   Asia; Australasia; Australia
DE Neobidessodes [Checklists /  / ] [Indonesia / West Papua / ] [Australia
   /  / ]. 
   Neobidessodes darwiniensis [Northern Territory /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Dytiscidae
OR Neobidessodes - Hendrich & Balke in Hendrich, Hawlitschek & Balke 2009
   (Dytiscidae): [Key to species, Amended key, p. 18]. 
   Neobidessodes darwiniensis (Dytiscidae): [Sp nov, Northern Territory, P.
   15].

   lepicoelia, and S. sluiteri (Teleostei, Labrisomidae), with comments on

AU Baldwin, Carole C. (baldwinc@si.edu)

   Weigt, Lee A.

SO ZooKeys
VL 79
PS 21-72
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=453a553a48a53cb80d40f8d16c8816ee&issue_id=99
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/1045/seven-new-species-w
   ithin-western-atlantic-starksia-atlantica-s-lepicoelia-and-s-sluiteri-te
   leostei-labrisomidae-with-com
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Specimens of Starksia were collected throughout the western Atlantic,
   and a 650-bp portion of the mitochondrial gene cytochrome oxidase-c
   subunit I (COl) was sequenced as part of a re-analysis of species
   diversity of western Central Atlantic shorefishes. A neighbor-joining
   tree constructed from the sequence data suggests the existence of
   several cryptic species. Voucher specimens from each genetically
   distinct lineage and color photographs of vouchers taken prior to
   dissection and preservation were examined for diagnostic morphological
   characters. The results suggest that Starksia atlantica, Starksia
   lepicoelia, and Starksia sluiteri are species complexes, and each
   comprises three or more species. Seven new species are described. DNA
   data usually support morphological features, but some incongruence
   between genetic and morphological data exists. Genetic lineages are only
   recognized as species if supported by morphology. Genetic lineages
   within western Atlantic Starksia generally correspond to geography, such
   that members of each species complex have a very restricted geographical
   distribution. Increasing geographical coverage of sampling locations
   will almost certainly increase the number of Starksia species and
   species complexes recognized in the western Atlantic. Combining
   molecular and morphological investigations is bringing clarity to the
   taxonomy of many genera of morphologically similar fishes and increasing
   the number of currently recognized species. Future phylogenetic studies
   should help resolve species relationships and shed light on patterns of
   speciation in western Atlantic Starksia.
C1 Baldwin, Carole C.; National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian
   Institution, Washington, D.C. 20560, USA, USA.
EM baldwinc@si.edu

   &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology

   Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic

DT Article
TI On some Cuban species of the genus Longior Travassos & Kloss, 1958
   (Oxyurida, Hystrignathidae), with description of a new species.
AU Morffe, Jans (jans@ecologia.cu) 
   Garcia, Nayla
SO ZooKeys
VL 78
PS 1-14
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=26c100009f747e09be5b788f5bdb90e7&issue_id=96
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/958/on-some-cuban-specie
   s-of-the-genus-longior-travassos-kloss-1958-oxyurida-hystrignathidae-wit
   h-description-of-a-new-speci
LA English
U1 1
U2 3
AB Longior zayasi Coy, Garca & Alvarez, 1993 is established as incertae
   sedis because the males (declared as the holotype) are inconsistent with
   the generic diagnosis, particularly in relation to the morphology of the
   head and tail. Thus, the females of Longior zayasi species (which agree
   with the generic diagnosis) are renamed and re-described as Longior
   longior Morffe & Garca sp. n. We also described males found in the
   sample and considered as conspecific with the new species. A comparative
   table with the measurements of the most of the records of Longior
   longior is given. The male of Longior similis Morffe, Garca & Ventosa,
   2009 is described from the type locality of the species and compared
   with the known males of the genus. A key to the females of the Cuban
   Longior is given.

DT Article
TI On the identity of the fossil aquatic beetles from the Tertiary
   localities in the southern part of the Upper Rhine Graben (Coleoptera,
   Hydrophilidae, Dytiscidae).
AU Martin, Fikacek (mfikacek@gmail.com) 
   Hajek, Jiri
   Schmied, Heiko
SO ZooKeys
VL 78
PS 15-25
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=26c100009f747e09be5b788f5bdb90e7&issue_id=96
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/800/on-the-identity-of-t
   he-fossil-hydrophilid-beetles-from-the-tertiary-localities-in-the-southe
   rn-part-of-the-upper-rhine-g
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This study focuses on the fossil beetles assigned previously to the
   family Hydrophilidae described from the localities in the southern part
   of the Upper Rhine Graben: Brunstatt (France, Alsace) and Kleinkems
   (Germany, Baden-Wurttemberg) (both dated ca. to Eocene-Oligocene
   boundary, 34 Ma). The identity of Escheria convexa Forster, 1891 is
   fixed by the designation of its neotype, the species is redescribed,
   illustrated, transferred from the hydrophilid genus Hydrobius Leach,
   1815 to the genus Copelatus Erichson, 1832 (Coleoptera: Adephaga:
   Dytiscidae) and compared with other fossil representatives of Copelatus.
   The identity of the remaining three species, Hydrobius crassipunctatus
   (Forster, 1891), Hydrobius dimidiatus (Forster, 1891) and Hydrobius
   punctulatus (Forster, 1891), is briefly evaluated on the basis of the
   original descriptions and illustrations only, because their types were
   lost or destroyed during World War II; all three species are removed
   from the fossil record of the Hydrophiloidea and placed into Polyphaga
   incertae sedis. The geology and stratigraphy of Brunnstatt and Kleinkems
   are discussed briefly.

   CZ-148 00 Praha 2, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.

   subordinate taxa, Fossil species, p. 21].

   P. 18; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Redefinition of the genus Allonychiurus Yoshii, 1995 (Collembola,
   Onychiuridae) with description of a new species from China.
AU Sun, Xin
   Chen, Jian-Xiu
   Deharveng, Louis (deharven@mnhn.fr) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 78
PS 27-41
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=26c100009f747e09be5b788f5bdb90e7&issue_id=96
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/977/redefinition-of-the-
   genus-allonychiurus-yoshii-1995-collembola-onychiuridae-with-description
   -of-a-new-species-from-china
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB In this paper, we describe a new species of the genus Allonychiurus
   Yoshii, 1995, characterized by the presence of an apical swelling on the
   fourth antennal segment as well as a combination of chaetotaxic and
   pseudocellar characters. The genus Allonychiurus is redefined. Four of
   its species are considered as incertae sedis: Allonychiurus
   michelbacheri (Bagnall, 1948), Allonychiurus spinosus (Bagnall, 1949),
   Allonychiurus caprariae (Dallai, 1969) and Allonychiurus sensitivus
   (Handschin, 1928). The three species Allonychiurus borensis (Beruete,
   Arbea & Jordana, 1994), Allonychiurus sensilatus (Thibaud & Massoud,
   1979) and Allonychiurus vandeli (Cassagnau, 1960) are removed from
   Allonychiurus and placed in Micronychiurus Bagnall, 1949,
   Thalassaphorura Bagnall, 1949 and Spinonychiurus Weiner, 1996
   respectively. The synonymy of Thibaudichiurus Weiner, 1996 with
   Allonychiurus is rejected and Allonychiurus foliatus (Rusek, 1967) and
   Allonychiurus mariangeae (Thibaud & Lee, 1994) are re-allocated to
   Thibaudichiurus. List and identification key to the world species of the
   genus are given.

   CP50, 45, rue Buffon, 75005 Paris, France, France.
EM deharven@mnhn.fr

OI Sun, Xin/0000-0002-2782-649X

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

TI Cachiporrini, a remarkable new tribe of Lamprosomatinae (Coleoptera,
   Chrysomelidae) from South America.
AU Chamorro, Maria Lourdes (lourdes.chamorro@gmail.com) 
   Konstantinov, Alexander S.

   kable-new-tribe-of-lamprosomatinae-coleoptera-chrysomelidae-from-south-a
   merica
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new genus and species of Lamprosomatinae, Cachiporra extremaglobosa
   Chamorro & Konstantinov, is described from Brazil. A new tribe,
   Cachiporrini, is proposed. The first phylogenetic analysis of
   Lamprosomatinae based on adult morphological caharacters is conducted.
   Comparisons are made among lamprosomatine tribes and genera. A key to
   tribes is provided.

TI On the placement of the Cretaceous orthopteran Brauckmannia groeningae
   from Brazil, with notes on the relationships of Schizodactylidae
   (Orthoptera, Ensifera).
AU Heads, Sam W. (swheads@illinois.edu) 
   Leuzinger, Lea
SO ZooKeys
VL 77
PS 17-30
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=26c100009f747e09be5b788f5bdb90e7&issue_id=95
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/769/abstract/on-the-plac
   ement-of-the-cretaceous-orthopteran-brauckmannia-groeningae-from-brazil-
   with-notes-on-the-relationships-of-sc
LA English
U1 1
U2 7
AB The fossil orthopteran Brauckmannia groeningae Martins-Neto (Orthoptera,
   Ensifera) from the Early Cretaceous Crato Formation of Brazil, currently
   misplaced at both the genus and family level, is transferred to the
   family Schizodactylidae and assigned to the extant genus Schizodactylus
   Brulle; ergo, Brauckmannia enters synonymy under Schizodactylus and
   Brauckmanniidae enters synonymy under Schizodactylidae. Schizodactylus
   groeningae (Martins-Neto), comb. n. agrees in size and general habitus
   with extant members of the genus, but can be readily separated by the
   robust, subovoid form of the metatibiae and the distinctive morphology
   of the lateral metabasitarsal processes. This species represents the
   first fossil occurrence of Schizodactylidae and the only New World
   record of this ancient lineage. Phylogenetic relationships of the
   schizodactylids are reviewed and a sister-group relationship with
   Grylloidea advocated based on a reappraisal of morphological and
   molecular evidence.
C1 Heads, Sam W.; Illinois Natural History Survey, Institute of Natural
   Resource Sustainability, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign,
   Illinois, USA, USA.
EM swheads@illinois.edu

SN 1313-2970

   position; Evolution; Land zones; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Ensifera [Phylogeny /  / ]. 
   Schizodactylidae [Land zones / New World / New record] [Cretaceous /  /
   First fossil record].

   Ensifera (Saltatoria).

TI Review of the European Greenomyia Brunetti (Diptera, Mycetophilidae)
   with new descriptions of females.
AU Kurina, Olavi (olavi.kurina@emu.ee) 
   Hedmark, Kjell
   Karstrom, Mats
   Kjaerandsen, Jostein
SO ZooKeys
VL 77
PS 31-50
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=26c100009f747e09be5b788f5bdb90e7&issue_id=95
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/936/abstract/review-of-t
   he-european-greenomyia-brunetti-diptera-mycetophilidae-with-new-descript
   ions-of-females
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB The females of the four continental Greenomyia Brunetti species in
   Europe are associated with the males, diagnosed and keyed, providing the
   first association and description of the females of G. baikalica
   Zaitzev, 1994 and G. stackelbergi Zaitzev, 1982. Colour photographs of
   their habitus and line drawings of their female terminalia are provided.
   Greenomyia mongolica Lastovka & Matile, 1974 is found to be a senior
   synonym of Greenomyia theresae Matile, 2002. syn. n. The diagnostic
   characters used to distinguish between Greenomyia and Neoclastobasis
   Ostroverkhova in keys did not hold up to a closer scrutiny and leave the
   status of Neoclastobasis as separate genus questionable.

TI Review of the genus Isodemis Diakonoff (Lepidoptera, Tortricidae) from
   China, with description of three new species.
AU Sun, Yinghui
   Li, Houhun (lihouhun@nankai.edu.cn) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 77
PS 51-64
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=26c100009f747e09be5b788f5bdb90e7&issue_id=95
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/937/abstract/review-of-t
   he-genus-isodemis-diakonoff-lepidoptera-tortricidae-from-china-with-desc
   ription-of-three-new-species
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The genus Isodemis Diakonoff, 1952 in China is reviewed, with seven
   species recognized. Three new species are described: I. quadrata sp. n.,
   I. guangxiensis sp. n. and I. hainanensis sp. n. The e female of I.
   stenotera Diakonoff, 1983 is described for the first time. Variation
   within I. illiberalis (Meyrick, 1918) and I. stenotera is briefly
   discussed. Images of the adults and genitalia are provided, along with a
   key to the described species.

   China, China.

TI Review of the genus Merulempista Roesler, 1967 (Lepidoptera, Pyralidae)
   from China, with description of two new species.
AU Ren, Yingdang
   Liu, Shurong
   Li, Houhun (lihouhun@nankai.edu.cn) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 77
PS 65-75
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=26c100009f747e09be5b788f5bdb90e7&issue_id=95
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/938/abstract/review-of-t
   he-genus-merulempista-roesler-1967-lepidoptera-pyralidae-from-china-with
   -description-of-two-new-species
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The genus Merulempista Roesler, 1967 is reviewed for China. Of the four
   species treated in this paper, Merulempista rubriptera Li & Ren, sp. n.
   and M. digitata Li & Ren, sp. n. are described as new; M. cyclogramma
   (Hampson, 1896) is newly recorded for China, and its taxonomic position
   is briefly discussed. Photographs of the adults and genitalia are
   provided, along with a key to the known Chinese species

DT Article
TI Twenty-four new species of Polycentropus (Trichoptera,
   Polycentropodidae) from Brazil.
AU Hamilton, Steven W. (hamiltonsw@apsu.ed) 
   Holzenthal, Ralph W.
SO ZooKeys
VL 76
PS 1-53
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=26c100009f747e09be5b788f5bdb90e7&issue_id=94
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/790/twenty-four-new-spec
   ies-of-polycentropus-trichoptera-polycentropodidae-from-brazil
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Twenty-four new species of the caddisfly genus Polycentropus (Insecta:
   Trichoptera: Polycentropodidae) occurring in Brazil are diagnosed,
   described, and the male genitalia of each are illustrated. Eighteen of
   the new species are placed in the Polycentropus jorgenseni species
   complex of the Polycentropus gertschi group of New World Polycentropus
   sensu lato. Furthermore, 6 new species within the Polycentropus gertschi
   group (Polycentropus ancistrus sp. n., Polycentropus boraceia sp. n.,
   Polycentropus carioca sp. n., Polycentropus froehlichi sp. n.,
   Polycentropus galharada sp. n., and Polycentropus graciosa sp. n.) are
   placed in an informal diagnostic cluster of species with Polycentropus
   urubici Holzenthal and Almeida. Ten of the other Polycentropus gertschi
   group species form a second cluster of diagnostically similar species,
   the Polycentropus soniae cluster (Polycentropus caaete sp. n.,
   Polycentropus carolae sp. n., Polycentropus cheliceratus sp. n.,
   Polycentropus fluminensis sp. n., Polycentropus itatiaia sp. n.,
   Polycentropus minero sp. n., Polycentropus santateresae sp. n.,
   Polycentropus soniae sp. n., Polycentropus tripui sp. n., and
   Polycentropus virginiae sp. n.). Two of the remaining 8 new species are
   included in the Polycentropus jorgenseni species complex (Polycentropus
   cipoensis sp. n. and Polycentropus verruculus sp. n.), while the
   remaining 6 are unique and cannot be placed in one of the groups at this
   time (Polycentropus acinaciformis sp. n., Polycentropus amphirhamphus
   sp. n., Polycentropus cachoeira sp. n., Polycentropus inusitatus sp. n.,
   Polycentropus paprockii sp. n. and Polycentropus rosalysae sp. n.).
C1 Hamilton, Steven W.; Austin Peay State University, The Center for Field
   Biology, P.O. Box 4718, Clarksville, Tennessee 37044, USA, USA.
EM hamiltonsw@apsu.ed
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Evolution; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America

   region /  / ].

   graciosa; Polycentropus inusitatus; Polycentropus itatiaia;
   Polycentropus minero; Polycentropus paprockii; Polycentropus rosalysae;
   Polycentropus santateresae; Polycentropus soniae; Polycentropus tripui;
   Polycentropus verruculus; Polycentropus virginiae [Brazil /  / New
   species].

   Townes, 1970 (Hymenoptera, Ichneumonidae) are described. A new diagnosis

TI Chordodes mizoramensis (Nematomorpha, Gordiida), a new species of
   horsehair worm from Mizoram, North-East India.
AU Schmidt-Rhaesa, Andreas (andreas.schmidt-rhaesa@uni-hamburg.de) 
   Lalramliana
SO ZooKeys
VL 75
PS 1-8
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=26c100009f747e09be5b788f5bdb90e7&issue_id=93
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/812/chordodes-mizoramens
   is-nematomorpha-gordiida-a-new-species-of-horsehair-worm-from-mizoram-no
   rth-east-india
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Chordodes mizoramensis, a new species of freshwater gordiid horsehair
   worm, is described from Mizoram, NE India on the basis of scanning
   electron microscopic and morphometric studies. The new species can be
   distinguished from its congeners in that the apical filaments of the
   crowned areoles are branched several times, a pattern that has not been
   observed in other species. An additional distinguishing character is
   that it has more bulging areoles, which are distributed among simple
   areoles alone or in groups, do not form clear patterns
C1 Schmidt-Rhaesa, Andreas; Zoological Museum, University Hamburg,
   Martin-Luther-King-Platz 3, 20146 Hamburg, Germany, Germany.

DT Article
TI Coynema gen. n., a new genus of nematode (Thelastomatoidea,
   Hystrignathidae) parasites of Passalidae (Coleoptera) from Cuba.
AU Rodriguez, Jans Morffe (jans@ecologia.cu) 
   Rodriguez, Nayla Garcia
SO ZooKeys
VL 75
PS 9-19
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=26c100009f747e09be5b788f5bdb90e7&issue_id=93
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/809/coynema-gen-n-a-new-
   genus-of-nematode-thelastomatoidea-hystrignathidae-parasites-of-passalid
   ae-coleoptera-from-cuba
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The new genus Coynema gen. n. is described as parasite of the two
   passalid beetles from Cuba: Passalus interstitialis Escholtz, 1829 (type
   host) and Passalus pertyi Kaup, 1869. Females are characterized by the
   shape of their cephalic end, cervical cuticle unarmed, a sub-cylindrical
   procorpus with its base abruptly dilated, fore region of intestine
   dilated as a sac-like structure, genital system didelphic-amphidelphic
   and eggs markedly ovoid and smooth-shelled. Males have a digestive
   system similar to females, tail sharply pointed, bearing a Y-like
   thickening of the dorsal cuticle. They also present a big, median,
   mammiform pre-cloacal papillae and a pair of small, sub-dorsal
   pre-cloacal papillae anterior to the cuticular thickening of the tail.
C1 Rodriguez, Jans Morffe; Instituto de Ecologia y Sistematica, Carretera
   de Varona km 31/2, Capdevila, Boyeros, A.P. 8029, C.P. 10800, Ciudad de
   La Habana, Cuba, Cuba.
EM jans@ecologia.cu
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Parasitology
SN 1313-2970

   morphology; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth
   parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land zones; Neotropical region; Central
   America; West Indies
DE Coynema poeyi [General morphology /  / parasite systematics]
   [Coleopteran hosts / Passalus interstitialis / ] [ / Passalus pertyi / ]
   [Cuba / Holguin, La Habana & Pinar del Rio provinces / ]. 
   Passalus interstitialis; Passalus pertyi [Nematode parasites / Coynema
   poeyi / Parasite systematics & morphology] [Cuba / Holguin, La Habana &
   Pinar del Rio provinces / ].

TI A new species of Amblyodus Westwood, 1878 (Coleoptera, Melolonthidae,
   Dynastinae) from South America.
AU Grossi, Paschoal Coelho (paschoal.grossi@gmail.com) 
   Grossi, Everardo Jose
SO ZooKeys
VL 75
PS 21-28
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=26c100009f747e09be5b788f5bdb90e7&issue_id=93
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/884/a-new-species-of-amb
   lyodus-westwood-1878-coleoptera-melolonthidae-dynastinae-from-south-amer
   ica
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A second species of Amblyodus Westwood, 1878, Amblyodus castroi sp. n.,
   is described from the northern South America based on 12 specimens from
   Brazil and Peru (Amazonian subregion). The new species is here compared
   with the type species of the genus, Amblyodus taurus Westwood, 1878 and
   both species and their male genitalia are illustrated. Diagnostic
   characters for the genus are discussed, especially the metatibial teeth.
   A distribution map including the type species and the new species is
   provided. The genus Amblyodus is recorded for the first time from Peru
   and from Brazil states of Para and Rondonia.
C1 Grossi, Paschoal Coelho; Universidade Federal do Parana, Centro
   Politecnico, Departamento de Zoologia, Caixa Postal 19007, CEP
   81531-980, Curitiba, Parana, Brazil, Brazil.
EM paschoal.grossi@gmail.com

OI Grossi, Paschoal C/0000-0001-6601-5967

SN 1313-2970

   zones; Neotropical region; South America

   Para & Rondonia / New record] [Peru / Junin & Ucayali / ]. 
   Amblyodus castroi [Brazil /  / New species] [Peru /  / ].

TI Description of two new Lophocampa Harris from the Dominican Republic
   (Arctiidae, Arctiinae).
AU Vincent, Benoit (amastus@gmail.com) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 75
PS 69-78
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journal_home_page.php?journal_id=1&page=current_i
   ssue&SESID=26c100009f747e09be5b788f5bdb90e7&issue_id=93
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/811/description-of-two-n
   ew-lophocampa-harris-from-the-dominican-republic-arctiidae-arctiinae-
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Lophocampa Harris are described from the Dominican
   Republic, Lophocampa lineata sp. n. based on two males, and Lophocampa
   albitegula sp. n. based on three females. The habitus and genitalia are
   illustrated. The following nomenclatural changes are also proposed:
   Lophocampa albiguttata Boisduval, 1870, stat. rev. and Lophocampa
   brunnea Vincent, nom. n.

   location notes, p. 76; Removal from synonymy, Lophocampa albiguttata
   (Boisduval 1870), p. 74]. 
   Lophocampa brunnea (Arctiidae): [Nom nov, For Lophocampa montana Gaede
   1928, p. 73]. 
   Lophocampa caryae form. montana - Gaede 1928 (Arctiidae): [Raised to,
   Lophocampa montana, p. 73]. 
   Lophocampa lineata (Arctiidae): [Sp nov, Dominican Republic, P. 71]. 
   Lophocampa montana - Gaede 1928 (Arctiidae): [Preoccupied name replaced
   by, Lophocampa brunnea, p. 73; Raised from, Lophocampa caryae form.
   montana, p. 73]. 
   Lophocampa propinqua - Edwards 1884 (Arctiidae): [Diagnostic characters,
   P. 71; Status, As distinct species, p. 73].

PT J
AN ZOOR14811075019
DT Article
TI The grass is always greener on the other side: Triplectides Kolenati,
   1859 (Leptoceridae) and Marilia Mueller, 1880 (Odontoceridae) occupying
   cases of other Trichoptera species.
AU de Camargos, Lucas Marques (lmcamargosbio@gmail.com) 
   Oliveira Pes, Ana Maria
SO Acta Limnologica Brasiliensia
VL 23
IS 4
PS 353-356
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Aim: Larvae of Triplectides spp. and Marilia sp. occupying cases of
   other species are recorded and photographed; Methods: The material was
   collected in diferent sites and dates in Atlantic Forest and Central
   Amazon regions; Results:The Triplectides larvae seem to have an
   opportunistic behavior, occupying a great variety of cases, which
   relects their common habit of enter in hollow twigs instead of build
   complex cases. However, this behavior is not frequently recorded in
   Marilia larvae, and we believe that the diference on the roughness of
   the interior walls, as well as the diference of the color of the
   material of the cases limit the opportunistic behavior in this genus;
   Conclusions: Experimental studies with diferent species can help the
   understanding of this behavior in the light of adaptive values.
C1 de Camargos, Lucas Marques; Laboratorio de Taxonomia e Biologia de
   Trichoptera e Ephemeroptera, Coordenacao ede Pesquisas em Entomologia
   -CPEN, Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas de Amazonia - INPA, Petropolis,
   CP 478, CEP 69010-970, Manaus, AM, Brazil, Brazil.
EM lmcamargosbio@gmail.com

   Grumicha [Associations / Marilia (Trichoptera) / New record] [ /

   [Brazil / Atlantic Forest & Central Amazon region / ] [ /  / ].

DT Article
TI Four new Neotropical species of Anotylus with an interesting sexual
   dimorphism (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae: Oxytelinae).
AU Makranczy, Gy (makranczy@nhmus.hu) 
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 103
PS 43-64
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Following the discovery of an early Cretaceous Anotylus fossil in the
   Yixian Formation, (Beipiao City, Liaoning Province, NE China) displaying
   an interesting sexually dimorphic feature, four extant species with the
   same characteristic are described. These Neotropical Anotylus species
   have a modification of the anterior pronotal corners in males and in
   addition to the modification observable in the fossil, also a strong
   enlargement of the temples. The new species were mostly found in flight
   intercept traps, all but one represented by a single male specimen each:
   Anotylus arellanoae sp. n. (Bolivia: Santa Cruz), A. engeli sp. n.
   (Bolivia: Cochabamba), A. debae sp. n. (Ecuador: Zamora-Chinchipe), A.
   deboeri sp. n. (Panama: Panama and Chiriqui). Habitus, important
   morphological details and male genitalia are illustrated for all
   species. With 67 figures.
C1 Makranczy, Gy; Hungarian Nat Hist Museum, Dept Zool, Baross Utca 13,
   Budapest, H-1088, Hungary, Hungary.
EM makranczy@nhmus.hu
SC Zoology
SN 0521-4726
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   Central America; South America
DE Anotylus arellanoae; Anotylus engeli [Bolivia /  / New species]. 
   Anotylus debae [Ecuador /  / New species]. 
   Anotylus deboeri [Panama /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Staphylinidae
OR Anotylus arellanoae (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Bolivia, P. 46]. 
   Anotylus debae (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Ecuador, P. 49]. 
   Anotylus deboeri (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Panama, P. 51]. 
   Anotylus engeli (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Bolivia, P. 47]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14811074540
DA 2020-09-17

TI On some Palaearctic click beetles deposited in the Hungarian Natural
   History Museum (Coleoptera: Elateridae).
AU Platia, G. (pinoplatia-@teletu.it) 
   Nemeth, T.
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 103
PS 65-106
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Twenty-two new species of Elateridae are described: Agriotes danieli sp.
   n. (Iran), Agriotes laszlopappi sp. n. (Afghanistan), Agriotes
   podlussanyi sp. n. (Turkey), Agriotes rahmei sp. n. (Syria), Agriotes
   silvanensis sp. n. (Turkey), Agriotes szekelykalmani sp. n. (Turkey),
   Ampedus ottomerkli sp. n. (Portugal), Athous (Haplathous) evae sp. n.
   (Spain), Athous (Haplathous) ilniczkyi sp. n. (Georgia: Abkhazia)),
   Athous (Haplathous) korsosi sp. n. (Russia: Daghestan), Athous
   (Orthathous) abkhazianus sp. n. (Georgia: Abkhazia)), Athous
   (Orthathous) fodorjenoi sp. n. (Macedonia), Athous (Orthathous)
   hercegovinensis sp. n. (Bosnia-Herzegovina), Athous (Orthathous)
   jakupicicola sp. n. (Macedonia), Athous (Orthathous) podlussanyi sp. n.
   (Turkey), Athous (Orthathous) slavonicus sp. n. (Croatia), Denticollis
   suzannae sp. n. (Bulgaria), Lacon nadaii sp. n. (Iran), Melanotus
   (Spheniscosomus) kangwonensis sp. n. (South Korea), Mulsanteus istvani
   sp. n. (Iran), Pittonotus iranicus sp. n. (Iran), Poemnites
   katalinbodorae sp. n. (South Korea). New distributional data for species
   of the genera Agriotes, Ampedus, Athous, Cidnopus, Dalopius,
   Denticollis, Idotarmonoides, Lacon, Megathous, Melanotus, Plastocerus
   and Tetrigus are given. The female of Dalopius apterus PLATIA et
   GUDENZI, 2006 unknown at the time of its description, is figured. With
   102 figures.

DT Article
TI Various species of Spermophagus (Coleoptera, Chrysomelidae: Bruchinae)
   in the Hungarian Natural History Museum, Budapest.
AU Delobel, A. (delobel.alex@aliceadsl.fr) 
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 103
PS 107-116
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eighteen species of Spermophagus SCHONHERR, 1833 collected in Ghana,
   Iran, South Africa, Syria, Taiwan, and Thailand by several expeditions
   of Hungarian entomologists and deposited in the Hungarian Natural
   History Museum are listed. Spermophagus arcis sp. n. is described from
   Western Syria; it is assigned to the S. sericeus species-group. One
   species (S. borowieci ANTON, 1996) is recorded for the first time from
   Iran, three species (S. caricus DECELLE, 1982, S. confusus BOROWIEC,
   1986, S. pubiventris BAUDI, 1886) from Syria, one species (S. ruandanus
   BOROWIEC, 1991) from South Africa, and three species (S. albosparsus
   GYLLENHAL, 1833, S. ligatus CHEVROLAT, 1877, S. sinensis Plc, 1918) from
   Thailand. With 3 figures.
C1 Delobel, A.; 47 Ave Paul Langevin, Fontenay Aux Roses, F-92260, France,
   France.
EM delobel.alex@aliceadsl.fr

DT Article
TI New Neotropical Hydroptilidae (Trichoptera).
AU Olah, J. (profolah@gmail.com) 
   Johanson, K.A.
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 103
PS 117-255
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Eighty-two new species are described from Bolivia (1 sp.), Ecuador (4
   spp.), French Guiana (37 spp.), Mexico (1 sp.) and Peru (41 spp.). Two
   of the new species were collected from both Ecuador and Peru. The new
   species are classified into the genera Abtrichia MOSELY, 1939 (2
   spp.),Acostatrichia MOSELY, 1939 (1 sp.), Alisotrichia FLINT, 1964 (3
   spp.), Angrisanoia OZDIKMEN, 2008 (2 spp.), Betrichia MOSELY, 1939 (1
   sp.), Cerasmatrichia FLINT, HARRIS et BOTOSANEANU, 1994 (2 spp.),
   Ceratotrichia FLINT, 1992 (1 sp.), Flintiella ANGRISANO, 1995 (2 spp.),
   Hydroptila DALMAN, 1819 (7 spp.), Leucotrichia MOSELY, 1934 (2 spp.),
   Metrichia Ross, 1938 (6 spp.), Neotrichia MORTON, 1905 (25 spp.),
   Ochrotrichia Ross, 1938 (15 spp.), Orinocotrichia HARRIS, FLINT et
   HOLZENTHAL, 2002 (1 sp.), Oxyethira EATON, 1873 (7 spp.), Ragatrichia
   gen. n. (2 spp.), Rhyacopsyche MULLER, 1879 (2 spp.) and Zumatrichia
   MOSELY, 1937 (2 spp.). New records of 35 species in 22 genera are given.
   The following species were transferred to other genera: Rhyacopsyche
   patulosa WASMUND et HOLZENTHAL, 2007 to Ochrotrichia; Rhyacopsyche
   otarosa WASMUND et HOLZENTHAL, 2007 to Angrisanoia; Ochrotrichia dietzi
   FLINT, 1974 to Ragatrichia; Rhyacopsyche garuhape ANGRISANO et SGANGA,
   2009 to Ragatrichia; and Rhyacopsyche yatay ANGRISANO, 1989 to
   Ragatrichia. With 309 figures.
C1 Olah, J.; Tarjan U 28, Debrecen, H-4032, Hungary, Hungary.
EM profolah@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0521-4726

   Taxonomic position; Land zones; Nearctic region; Neotropical region;
   North America; South America

OR Abtrichia veva (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, French Guiana, P. 153]. 
   Acostatrichia buborektala (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Peru, P. 155]. 
   Alisotrichia kantala (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Peru, P. 143].

DT Article
TI Descriptions of eight new Pseudolucia species from Chile (Lepidoptera,
   Lycaenidae: Polyommatinae).
AU Benyamini, D.
   Balint, Zs (balint@nhmus.hu) 
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 103
PS 257-276
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Eight species of Pseudolucia NABOKOV, 1945 from Chile are described,
   five from the P. andina species group (P. barrigai sp. n. from Maule
   Region, P. faundezi sp. n. from Araucania Region, P. johnsoni sp. n.
   from Bio Bio Region, P. luzmaria sp. n. from Coquimbo Region, and P.
   munozae sp. n. from Maule Region), one from the P. collina species group
   (P. zoellneri sp. n. from Maule Region), and two from the P. plumbea
   species group (P. sigal sp. n. from Coquimbo Region and P. valentina sp.
   n. from Maule Region). Data on biology and distribution of the species
   described are provided, with additional notes on nomenclature and
   taxonomy. A list of all known Pseudolucia species with basic information
   on their distributions is also given. With 23 figures.
C1 Balint, Zs; Hungarian Nat Hist Museum, Dept Zool, Baross Utca 13,
   Budapest, H-1088, Hungary, Hungary.
EM balint@nhmus.hu
SC Zoology
SN 0521-4726

   zones; Neotropical region; South America

   distribution].

   Pseudolucia munozae; Pseudolucia sigal; Pseudolucia valentina;
   Pseudolucia zoellneri [Chile /  / New species].

   Pseudolucia johnsoni (Lycaenidae): [Sp nov, Chile, P. 262]. 
   Pseudolucia luzmaria (Lycaenidae): [Sp nov, Chile, P. 263]. 
   Pseudolucia munozae (Lycaenidae): [Sp nov, Chile, P. 265]. 
   Pseudolucia sigal (Lycaenidae): [Sp nov, Chile, P. 269].

TI Twelve new Bracon Fabricius, 1804 species from the Western Palaearctic
   Region (Hymenoptera, Braconidae: Braconini).
AU Papp, J. (j.papp1933@gmail.com) 
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 103
PS 277-314
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The following twelve new Bracon FABRICIUS, 1804 species are described:
   B. (Lucobracon) attilae (Turkey), B. (Glabobracon) dupleola (Spain), B.
   (Glabobracon) flamargo (Bulgaria), B. (Glabobracon) fucosus (Denmark),
   B. (Glabobracon) gijswijti (Spain), B. (Bracon) gumis (Spain: Canary
   Islands), B. (Glabobracon) latitergit (Hungary), B. (Lucobracon) merkli
   (Hungary), B. (Glabobracon) mopux (Germany, Denmark, Romania, Sweden),
   B. (Glabobracon) munki (Denmark, Romania), B. (Lucobacon) roznevani
   (Algeria) and B. (Bracon) xaxon (Armenia). The types of the new species
   are deposited in the Museums Budapest, Helsinki and Leiden. With 132
   figures.

DT Article
TI Redescriptions of eight species by Gy. Szepligeti belonging to the
   genera Calobracon, Diamblomera and Hemibracon with a new Diamblomera
   species (Hymenoptera, Braconidae: Braconinae).
AU Papp, J. (j.papp1933@gmail.com) 
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 103
PS 315-344
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Redescriptions are presented for eight braconine species in the genera
   Calobracon SZEPLIGETI, 1902, Diamblomera ENDERLEIN, 1920 and Hemibracon
   SZEPLIGETI, 1906. Diamblomera belaga sp. n. is described from Sarawak,
   Malaysia. Hemibracon lucidus SZEPLIGETI, 1911 is transferred to the
   genus Bathyaulax SZEPLIGETI, 1906. New synonym: Hemibracon excisus
   (SZEPLIGETI, 1901) = Iphiaulax carpalis SZEPLIGETI, 1904, syn. n. A key
   for the six species of Hemibracon described by SZEPLIGETI is given. With
   94 figures.

   Budapest, H-1088, Hungary, Hungary.

DT Article
TI A revision of the Palaearctic Periscelidinae with notes on some New
   World species (Diptera: Periscelididae).
AU Papp, L. (lpapp@flyer.gmail.com) 
   Withers, P.
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 103
PS 345-371
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The statuses of Periscelis annulipes LOEW, 1858, P. nigra (ZETTERSTEDT,
   1860) and P. winnertzii EGGER, 1862 as species are confirmed; P. nigra
   minor ssp. n. is described from Hungary. Myodris LIOY, 1864 is treated
   as a genus with M. annulata (FALLEN, 1813), M chinensis (L. PAPP et
   SZAPPANOS, 1997), M flinti (MALLOCH, 1915) (Nearctic), M. kabuli (L.
   PAPP, 1988) and M. piricercus (CARLES-TOLRA et VERDUGO PAEZ, 2009) as
   valid species. Some notes and genitalia figures are given also for the
   New World species of Scutops COQUILLETT, 1904. With 53 figures.
C1 Papp, L.; Hungarian Nat Hist Museum, Dept Zool, Baross U 13, Budapest,
   H-1088, Hungary, Hungary.
EM lpapp@flyer.gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0521-4726

   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

   region /  / Distribution].

ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Periscelididae
OR Periscelididae (Cyclorrhapha): [Key to genera, Holarctic, Male
   genitalia, p. 347]. 
   Myodris - Lioy 1864 (Periscelididae): [Key to species, P. 358]. 
   Periscelidinae (Periscelididae). 
   Periscelis annulipes - Loew 1858 (Periscelididae): [Redescription, P.
   349; Status, P. 345].

   P. 350; Status, P. 345]. 
   Periscelis nigra minor (Periscelididae): [Subsp nov, Hungary, P. 353]. 
   Periscelis winnertzii - Egger 1862 (Periscelididae): [Redescription, P.
   356; Status, P. 345].

PT J
AN ZOOR14811075132
DT Article
TI A review of New World Asiracinae (Hemiptera: Auchenorrhyncha:
   Delphacidae) with five new taxa.
AU Barringer, Lawrence E.
   Bartlett, Charles R. (Bartlett@udel.edu) 
SO Cicadina
VL 12
PS 7-39
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genera of New World asiracine planthoppers are reviewed and
   discussed in the context of new taxa discovered in canopy fogging
   samples from Ecuador. Twelve nomative genera, including 3 Ugyopinae and
   9 Asiracinae (1 new) are reported from the New World, although the
   generic identity of the single Asiraca species could not be verified. A
   key to New World asiracinae genera, excluding Asiraca, is provided. The
   new taxa include Pentasteira gen. nov. (Asiracinae: Platysystatini) with
   I species (P. albifrons n. sp.) and a new Tetrasteira (Asiracinae:
   Tetrasteirini), prompting a generic revision with three new described
   species (T. vulgaris, n. sp., T. trimaculata n. sp., and T. solata n.
   sp.). A key to the species of Tetrasteira is provided. Tetrasteira
   vulgaris n. sp. has been taken in large numbers in canopy fogging
   samples from terre firme forest in the Amazon basin in Ecuador.
C1 Bartlett, Charles R.; University of Delaware, Department of Entomology
   and Wildlife Ecology, 250 Townsend Hall, 531 S college Ave, Newark, DE
   19716-2160, USA, USA.
EM Bartlett@udel.edu
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; Neotropical region; North America; Central America; South
   America
DE Asiracinae [Land zones / New World / Key to genera] [ /  / Systematics].
   
   Pentasteira albifrons; Tetrasteira vulgaris [Ecuador /  / New species]. 
   Tetrasteira solata [Panama /  / New species] [Venezuela /  / ]. 
   Tetrasteira trimaculata [Mexico /  / New species] [Belize /  / ] [Costa
   Rica /  / ] [Honduras /  / ] [Panama /  / ] [Colombia /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Auchenorrhyncha,
   Fulgoroidea, Delphacidae
OR Asiracinae (Delphacidae): [Key to genera, New World, P. 12]. 
   Pentasteira (Delphacidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Platysystatini, Type
   species Pentasteira albifrons, p. 16]. 
   Pentasteira albifrons (Delphacidae): [Sp nov, Ecuador, P. 19]. 
   Tetrasteira - Muir 1926 (Delphacidae): [Key to species, P. 23]. 
   Tetrasteira solata (Delphacidae): [Sp nov, Panama, P. 28]. 
   Tetrasteira trimaculata (Delphacidae): [Sp nov, Belize, P. 31]. 
   Tetrasteira vulgaris (Delphacidae): [Sp nov, Ecuador, P. 34].

DT Article; Meeting paper
TI [Contribution on the knowledge of Thysanoptera of Coahuila, Mexico.]
FT Contribucion al Conocimiento de los Thysanoptera de Coahuila, Mexico.
AU Garcia Martinez, Oswaldo
   Johansen-Naime, Roberto
   Villarreal-Quintanilla, Jose
   Cambero-Campos, Jhonathan
   Retana-Salazar, Axel P. (axel.retana@ucr.ac.cr) 
SO Metodos en Ecologia y Sistematica
VL 6
IS 3
PS 15-26
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://metodosenecologiaysistematica.org//vol6%283%29.html
AW http://metodosenecologiaysistematica.org//vol6/vol6(3)/03-THRIPS%20DE%20
   COAHUILA%20MEMORIA%20%20FINAL%20MES%206(3).pdf
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Universidad AutonomaAgraria Antonio Narro (UAAAN), formalized in
   1997 a proyect study the state of Coahuila Thysanoptera and contribute
   to the knowledge of the entomofauna this group in the state, places
   where individuals are located, naming possible new species and determine
   crop pest species. From 1977 to 2010 collected thrips in five stages:
   1)1997-1998; 2) 2003; 3) 204; 4) 2007-2008 y 5) 2009-2010 visiting 26 of
   the 38 municipalities of the state, seeking wild vegetation, crops,
   weeds, sand dunes, around bodies or water and in urban areas, using
   entomological net, plastic bags, strike, dip and manual harvesting.
   Properly seated adults were identified by specialist from the
   Universidad NacionalAutonoma de Mexico and Costa Rica respectively.
   Identified 4 families, 29 genera and 59 species of thrips on 77 plant
   species.F. occidentalis, F. gossypiana, F. aurea, F. cephalica,
   Bregmatothrips sp., Thrips tabaci y Caliothripsphaseoliare pest of
   crops. There is potential to identify new species of the specimens
   obtained.
C1 Retana-Salazar, Axel P.; Programa Universitario de Biologia Aplicada
   (PUA), Centro de Investigacion en Estructuras Microscopicas (CIEMic),
   Ciudad de la Investigacion, Universidad de Costa Rica, 2060 San Jose,
   Costa Rica, Costa Rica.
EM axel.retana@ucr.ac.cr

PT J
AN ZOOR14811074209
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI [Diversity of thrips of Cono Sur. The case of arid zones in Jujuy,
   Argentina.]
FT La diversidad de thrips del Cono Sur. El caso de las zonas aridas en
   Jujuy, Argentina.
AU Zamar, Maria Ines (mizamar@inbial.unju.edu.ar) 
SO Metodos en Ecologia y Sistematica
VL 6
IS 3
PS 71-88
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://metodosenecologiaysistematica.org//vol6%283%29.html
AW http://metodosenecologiaysistematica.org//vol6/vol6(3)/10-LOS%20THRIPS%2
   0DEL%20CONO%20SUR%20FORMATO%20DE%20LA%20MEMORIA%20FINAL%202.pdf
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB Thysanoptera is represented by six families in the Neotropical region:
   Uzelothripidae, Merothripidae, Aeolothripidae, Heterothripidae,
   Thripidae and Phlaeothripidae, on wich about 140 genera and 523 species
   represent 18% and 9% of the world thrips fauna, respectively. There is a
   wide range of landscapes in Argentina, for this study we selected
   semi-arid and arid areas of the province of Jujuy (Prepuna and Puna)
   located between 1300-6200 masl. Within this paper we present the
   diversity, biological strategies and distribution of thrips in
   agricultural and natural ecosystems of these areas. Samples were
   colected over 124 species of plants (24 families) in 54 locations along
   an altitudinal gradient (2100 masl and 4150 masl) by different
   techniques and sampling frequencies. We found 21 genera and 35 species
   of the family Aeolothripidae, Heterothripidae, Thripidae and
   Aeolothripidae. The present study adds four genera and twelve species to
   the list of Thysanoptera fauna of Argentina. From periodic sampling on
   crops, natural vegetation and weeds, we expanded the number of host
   plants of most species of thrips tested. 91% of species collected were
   phytophagous (anthophylls, folivores and mixed diet), 6% were predators
   and 3% fungivores. Most of phytophagous species are anthophylls (22), 5
   species have mixed diets and 5 are folivores. The species that affect
   crops were: Frankliniella tuberosi Moulton, Frankliniella schultzei
   Trybom, Frankliniella occidentalis (Pergande), Frankliniella australis
   Morgan and Thrips tabaci Lindeman. The spontaneous vegetation shelters
   the same complex of thrips associated with crops and provide an
   alternative source of food. According to the levels of thrips-plant
   species specificity we distinguished generalists (polyphagous) and
   specialists (monophagous and oligophagous). Most oligophagous and
   monophagous species are associated with wild vegetation. The only gall
   species recorded was Pseudophilothrips sp. nov. that could be a
   biocontrol agent of the hemiparasite plant Ligaria cuneifolia (Ruiz et
   Pavon).
C1 Zamar, Maria Ines; Instituto de Biologia de la Altura-Universidad
   Nacional de Jujuy, Avda. Bolivia 1661, (4600) San Salvador de Jujuy,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM mizamar@inbial.unju.edu.ar
SC Zoology; Parasitology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1659-3049
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Habitat; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Thysanoptera [Plant hosts /  / New record] [Terrestrial habitat /
   Semiarid & arid zones / biology; distribution; faunal list] [Argentina /
   Jujuy / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta
OR Thysanoptera (Insecta): [Parasite; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14811074209
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14811075855
DT Article
TI New localities of Nehalennia speciosa (Charpentier, 1840) in
   southeastern Poland (Odonata: Coenagrionidae).
FT Nowe stanowiska iglicy malej Nehalennia speciosa (Charpentier, 1840) w
   poludniowo-wschodniej Polsce (Odonata: Coenagrionidae).
AU Daraz, B.
SO Odonatrix
VL 7
IS 1
PS 14-18
PD styczen 2011
PY 2011
LA Polish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new localities of Nehalennia speciosa were found in 2010 in
   southeastern Poland, in the south of the Sandomierz Basin (Kotlina
   Sandomierska), in two nature reserves "Bagno Przeclawskie"
   (50[degree]11[minute]15[second]N, 21[degree]25[minute]15[second]E, UTM
   EA35) and "Torfy" (50[degree]02[minute]38[second]N,
   21[degree]17[minute]45[second]E, EA24). They form - together with the
   localities near Bledow and in the nature reserve "Broduszurki" (BERNARD,
   DARAZ 2008; BERNARD et al. 2009; MISZTA, CUBER 2009) - the current
   southern range limit of the species distribution in Poland and Eastern
   Europe. Far outside this range, only a highly isolated and relict
   locality in the Southern Carpathians in the south of Romania is known
   (MANCI 2009, 2010). Other localities of N. speciosa situated to the
   south of the current species range - in the southern Ukraine, Slovakia
   and northern Romania - are only historical as they have not been
   confirmed during the last half-century (BERNARD, WILDERMUTH 2005; CHA
   2010). At the new localities, N. speciosa inhabits old peat excavations,
   with the water bodies abounding with Sphagnum sp. and Carex rostrata,
   and bounded by Molinia coerulea. It is typical of N. speciosa in the
   marginal zone of its distribution range to inhabit the partly secondary
   (i.e. anthropogenic) habitats and to use the vegetation composed of
   these species (cf. BERNARD, WILDERMUTH 2005; BERNARD, DARAZ 2008).
SC Zoology
SN 1733-8239
BD Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Nehalennia speciosa [Poland / Bagno Przeclawskie & Torfy / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Odonata
OR Nehalennia speciosa (Odonata): [New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14811075855
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AB The aphid genus Neothoracaphis Takahashi is reviewed, with the
   description of a new species, Neothoracaphis semicarpifolia sp. nov., on
   Quercus semicarpifolia and a newly recorded species, Neothoracaphis
   elongata (Takahashi) from China. Neothoracaphis hangzhouensis Zhang was
   considered as a junior synonym of Neothoracaphis yanonis (Matsumura),
   and a key to the species of Neothoracaphis was provided. Voucher
   specimens are deposited with the National Zoological Museum of China,
   Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China.

TI A new species of Habrobracon Ashmead (Hymenoptera: Braconidae) with
   notes on Indian species.
AU Akhtar, M.S. (msakhtar123@yahoo.com) 
   Ramamurthy, V.V.
SO Oriental Insects
VL 45

PS 194-201
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Habrobracon syzygiumae sp. nov., is described from New Delhi, India,
   with the specimens reared from Noctuides sp. (Lepidoptera: Crambidae) on
   Syzygium jambolanum (Lam.) (Myrtales: Myrtaceae). This new species is
   distinct in its propodeal carina, length: width ratio of I flagellar
   segment being 8:5, length of its ovipositor, and antenna, leg and
   mesoscutum, which are black. A key to the Indian species and comments on
   few Indian species are also given. The voucher specimens including the
   types are deposited with the National Pusa Collection, Division of
   Entomology, Indian Agricultural Research Institute, New Delhi, India.

DT Article
TI Additions to the Indian Aphelinidae (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea) - III:
   the genus Encarsia Foerster.
AU Hayat, Mohammad (hayat.mohd44@gmail.com) 
SO Oriental Insects
VL 45
IS 2-3
PS 202-274
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB Fifteen new species of Encarsia are described: Encarsia asfar sp. nov.,
   E. assamensis sp. nov., E. bolangera sp. nov., E. borkusiensis sp. nov.;
   E. brevicalcar sp. nov., E. farmani sp. nov., E. hitam sp. nov., E.
   hragila sp. nov., E. inida sp. nov., E. jowaiana sp. nov., E. khadijae
   sp. nov., E. meghalayana sp. nov., E. ossira sp. nov., E. reeda sp. nov.
   and E. sikkimiana sp. nov. Taxonomic accounts on 29 known species are
   given, of which nine are redescriptions while six are new records for
   India. The new records are as follows: E. asterobemisiae Viggiani and
   Mazzone, E. davidi Viggiani and Mazzone, E. diaspidicola (Silvestri), E.
   liliyingae Viggiani and Ren, E. lounsburyi (Berlese and Paoli) and E.
   nanjingensis Huang and Polaszek. Also, E. eurystoma Hayat is placed in
   synonymy with E. punicae Hayat, and E. opulenta (Silvestri) is excluded
   from Indian fauna as the material proved to be a misidentification for
   E. perplexa Huang and Polaszek. A key to the 79 (out of 83) Indian
   species of Encarsia is provided; of the four species not included, one
   species is considered incertae sedis and the other three are considered
   doubtful.

   202002, India, India.

   simulans sp. nov. and Antanambeus marmoratus sp. nov., are described
   based on single male specimens deposited with the Museum national

   also provided. Voucher material is deposited with the Museum national
   D'Histoire naturelle, Paris. Distributional data of the other two
   species of Antanambeus are also given.

TI A study on the Baris from India (Coleoptera: Curculionidae).
AU Ramesha, B. (b.ramesha@gmail.com) 
   Ramamurthy, V.V.
SO Oriental Insects
VL 45
IS 4
PS 304-392
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Twelve species of the genus Baris Germar (Coleoptera: Curculionidae)
   from India, including four new species described herein included in the
   study. An annotated checklist of 648 species known is given, which
   reveals that there are 44 species from the Oriental region. The eight
   known species are supplemented with more details and these re-described,
   and also a key to these provided.

DT Article
TI Freshwater scaled chrysophytes, Heliozoa and thaumatomonad flagellates
   from Edo State, Nigeria.
AU Wujek, D.E. (wujek1de@cmich.edu) 
   Kadiri, M.O.
   Kziedzic, R.M.
SO African Journal of Aquatic Science
VL 36
IS 2
PS 207-212
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A total of nine silica-scaled chrysophytes (Chrysophyceae: two species
   each in Spiniferomonas and Paraphysomonas; Synurophyceae: five
   Mallomonas species), 16 heliozoa, and two scaled flagellates were
   recorded from 19 samples collected from Edo State, Nigeria, over a
   period covering both dry and rainy seasons in 2006[long dash]2007.
   Identifications were based on transmission electron microscopy. Eleven
   are new records for Africa, including a new species of Mallomonas, M.
   cribridomus. Also observed were two siliceous scaled colourless
   free-living thaumatomonad flagellates, Thaumatomastix nigeriensis and
   Gyromitus limax, the latter also a new record for Africa.
C1 Wujek, D.E.; Department of Biology, Central Michigan University, Mount
   Pleasant, MI 48859, USA, USA.
EM wujek1de@cmich.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1608-5914; 1727-9364
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Africa
DE Chrysophyceae; Heliozoa; Thaumatomonadida [Nigeria / Edo State / Faunal
   list; new record]. 
   Gyromitus limax [Africa /  / New record]. 
   Mallomonas cribridomus [Nigeria /  / New species]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Mastigophora, Phytomastigophorea,
   Chrysomonadida, Sarcodina, Actinopoda, Heliozoea
OR Gyromitus limax (Protozoa): [New record]. 
   Thaumatomonadida (Protozoa): [New record]. 
   Chrysophyceae (Chrysomonadida): [New record]. 
   Mallomonas cribridomus (Chrysomonadida): [Sp nov, Nigeria, P. 207]. 
   Heliozoa (Heliozoea): [New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR14810073255
DT Article
TI Seasonal distribution of phytoplankton in the Aby lagoon system, Ivory
   Coast, West Africa.
AU Seu-Anoi, N.M.
   Kone, Y.J.-M. (kone-mathieu@hotmail.com) 
   Ouattara, A.
   Gourene, G.
SO African Journal of Aquatic Science
VL 36
IS 3
PS 321-330
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 1
U2 9
AB Seasonal variability of phytoplankton species composition, abundance and
   physical and chemical factors influencing phytoplankto n dynamics were
   investigated in the Aby lagoon system, south-eastern Ivory Coast,
   covering the main climatic seasons in 2006[long dash]2007. Seasonal and
   spatial variability of nutrient concentrations in the system were
   influenced by freshwater inflow from the Bia and Tanoe rivers. The
   decrease in the salinity gradient in Aby Lagoon, which is permanently
   stratified during the long dry season, increa sed the bottom inputs of
   soluble reactive phosphate and soluble reactive silicate which, in
   combination with good light penetration dur ing the long dry season,
   enhanced phytoplankton production in the system. During the rainy
   seasons, water discharges into the syste m washed phytoplankton biomass
   out, preventing the development of blooms. Overall, 192 taxa from eight
   phyla were recorded: Bacillariophyta (32%), Chlorophyta (31%),
   Cyanobacteria (23%), Euglenophyta (12%), Dinophyta (0.5%), Xanthophyta
   (0.5%), Chrysophyta (0.5%) and Rhodophyta (0.5%). During the long dry
   season, Cyanobacteria cells comprised >50% of the phytoplankton
   abundance. The main phytoplankton taxa responsible for this high
   abundance were Microcystis aeruginosa, Oscillatoria princeps,
   Pseudanabaena limnetica, Aphanizomenon sp. 2 and Anabaena planctonica.
C1 Kone, Y.J.-M.; Centre de Recherches Oceanologiques d'Abidjan, Rue des
   Pecheurs, 29 BP. V. 18 Abidjan, Ivory Coast, Ivory Coast.
EM kone-mathieu@hotmail.com
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine &Freshwater Biology

DT Article
TI The oldest fossil species of the rove beetle subfamily Oxyporinae
   (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae) from the Early Cretaceous (Yixian Formation,
   China) and its phylogenetic significance.
AU Yue, Yanli
   Ren, Dong
   Solodovnikov, Alexey (asolodovnikov@snm.ku.dk) 
SO Journal of Systematic Palaeontology
VL 9
IS 4
PS 467-471
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Oxyporus yixianus Solodovnikov&Yue sp. nov., a new Early Cretaceous
   fossil rove beetle species, is described from the Yixian Formation of
   Liaoning Province, China. It is clearly placed in Oxyporus Fabricius,
   1775, the extant and only genus of the subfamily Oxyporinae. In addition
   to the hitherto-known, much younger fossils of Oxyporinae, the
   significantly older age of this newly discovered species makes the
   currently accepted phylogenetic hypothesis that Oxyporinae is a basal
   lineage of the Staphylininae group more plausible. The remarkably modern
   and specialization-rich morphology of Oxyporus yixianus leads to the
   assumption that this species exemplifies a rather derived stage of
   divergence of Oxyporinae from the stem of the Staphylininae group.
   Divergence of Oxyporinae from the rest of the Staphylininae group
   lineage may have begun significantly earlier than the Early Cretaceous,
   and the fungus-associated biology of Oxyporinae is also apparently older
   than documented by Oxyporus yixianus.
C1 Solodovnikov, Alexey; Natural History Museum of Denmark, Zoological
   Museum, Universitetsparken 15, Copenhagen 2100, Denmark, Denmark.

PT J

DT Article
TI A new Early Miocene barnacle lineage and the roots of sea-turtle fouling
   Chelonibiidae (Cirripedia, Balanomorpha).
AU Harzhauser, Mathias (mathias.harzhauser@nhm-wien.ac.at) 
   Newman, William A.
   Grunert, Patrick
SO Journal of Systematic Palaeontology
VL 9
IS 4
PS 473-480
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB The origin of the mainly sea-turtle fouling balanomorph family
   Chelonibiidae is still poorly documented. Aside from an Eocene erratic
   specimen assigned to an extinct subfamily, the extant subfamily
   Chelonibiinae did not appear in the fossil record before the Late
   Miocene. Protochelonibiinae Harzhauser&Newman subfam. nov. is here
   introduced as an extinct sister-group of Chelonibiinae. The subfamily is
   known so far only from the proto-Mediterranean and the Paratethys seas
   and ranged from Early Miocene to Late Pliocene. Members of the subfamily
   are characterized by large walls with tripartite rostra which display
   distinct sutures on the external surface. The tripartite rostrum,
   however, has evolved independently several times in the evolution of the
   balanomorphs and cannot be treated as synapomorphy. The subfamily
   comprises one new genus and two species. Protochelonibia
   Harzhauser&Newman gen. nov. is the type genus of Protochelonibiinae and
   Protochelonibia submersa Harzhauser&Newman sp. nov. is introduced as
   type species of this genus. Chelonobia Capellinii (sic) De Alessandri,
   1895, from the Late Pliocene of Italy, reassigned as Protochelonibia
   capellinii (De Alessandri, 1895), is the youngest record of the
   subfamily. With the onset of the Pleistocene, Protochelonibiinae were
   fully replaced by Chelonibiinae, which had co-existed with
   Protochelonibiinae from the Late Miocene to the Pliocene. Surface
   imprints from the host substratum in one specimen of P. submersa are
   reminiscent of the sculpture of Caretta carapaces. Therefore, the
   Aquitanian Protochelonibia may be the earliest record of sea-turtle
   fouling in barnacles.

   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time
