DT Article
TI New rodents (Mammalia, Rodentia, Cricetidae) from the Verde Fauna of
   Arizona and the Maxum Fauna of California, USA, early Blancan Land
   Mammal Age.
AU Lindsay, Everett H. (ehlind@cox.net) 
   Czaplewski, Nicholas J.
SO Palaeontologia Electronica
VL 14
IS 3
PS 14.3.29A, 1-16
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://palaeo-electronica.org/2011_3/index.html
AW http://palaeo-electronica.org/2011_3/5_lindsay/5_lindsay.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The cricetid rodent Postcopemys repenningi, new genus and new species,
   is described from the Verde fauna in Arizona and the Maxum fauna in
   California. Two other rodents, Postcopemys maxumensis, new species, and
   Jacobsomys dailyi are reported herein from the Maxum fauna. Jacobsomys
   dailyi is described and Postcopemys valensis is reported (May et al.
   2011) from the Warren fauna in southern California. Jacobsomys verdensis
   had been reported from the Verde fauna by Czaplewski (1987a). These
   three faunas (the Warren and Maxum faunas in California and the Verde
   fauna in Arizona) are considered close to the Blancan/Hemphillian
   boundary, and the two genera Postcopemys and Jacobsomys are important
   small mammal taxa whose stage of evolution should prove useful for
   demonstrating the morphologic transition between Copemys and extant
   Peromyscus via Postcopemys, and between Bensonomys and extant Oryzomys
   via Jacobsomys, as well as for ordering mammalian faunas relative to the
   Blancan/Hemphillian boundary.
C1 Lindsay, Everett H.; Department of Geosciences, Gould-Simpson Building,
   University of Arizona, Tucson, Arizona 85721, USA, USA.
EM ehlind@cox.net
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1094-8074; 1094-8074

   Dentition; Evolution; Ecology; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene

   [Evolution / Evolutionary history / ] [Fossil assemblages /  / ]
   [Arizona /  / stratigraphical distribution] [California /  / ] [Pliocene
   / Early Blancan / ].

   Antecalomys phthanus (Muridae): [Taxonomic position, P. 7; Fossil]. 
   Bensonomys - Gazin (Muridae): [Status, P. 5; Fossil]. 
   Copemys twenteri - Czaplewski 1987 (Muridae): [Taxonomic position,

AN ZOOR14804026951
DT Article
TI Preliminary study of rodents from the Golliher B Assemblage of Meade
   County, Kansas, USA indicates an intense cold period near the end of the
   Pleistocene.
AU Martin, Robert A. (robert.martin@murraystate.edu) 
   Pelaez-Campomanes, Pablo
   Honey, James G.
SO Palaeontologia Electronica
VL 14
IS 3
PS 14.3.35A, 1-13
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://palaeo-electronica.org/2011_3/index.html
AW http://palaeo-electronica.org/2011_3/10_martin/10_martin.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB An assemblage of rodents recovered from a thin layer of sediments along
   Sand Creek on the Golliher Ranch in Meade County, Kansas, indicates that
   cold steppe conditions likely prevailed for a brief time near the close
   of the Pleistocene around 12,500 radiocarbon years ago. This environment
   is suggested by the northern disjunct rodents Zapus princeps, Microtus
   pennsylvanicus, Thomomys cf. talpoides and the presumed cold steppe vole
   Microtus (Pedomys) parmaleei, n. sp., plus the absence of cotton rats.
   Comparison of meadow vole m1 crown morphology diversity through the late
   Pleistocene in Kansas shows that the modern pattern of diversity
   developed in a brief period of 1500 years, possibly during the Younger
   Dryas interval. A cement-filled prism fold, a feature commonly
   encountered in extinct species of Mimomys with rooted molars, appears in
   three rootless first lower molars of Microtus pennsylvanicus. The
   Golliher B assemblage helps to fill in the late Pleistocene history of
   rodents in the ongoing Meade Basin Rodent Project.
C1 Martin, Robert A.; Department of Biological Sciences, Murray State
   University, Murray, KY 42071, USA, USA.
EM robert.martin@murraystate.edu

DT Article
TI Geology and mammalian paleontology of the Horned Toad Hills, Mojave
   Desert, California, USA.
AU May, Steven R. (steve.may@exxonmobil.com) 
   Woodburne, Michael O.
   Lindsay, Everett H.
   Albright, L. Barry
   Sarna-Wojcicki, Andrei
   Wan, Elmira
   Wahl, David B.
SO Palaeontologia Electronica
VL 14
IS 3
PS 14.3.28A, 1-63
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://palaeo-electronica.org/2011_3/index.html
AW http://palaeo-electronica.org/2011_3/11_may/11_may.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The Horned Toad Formation includes five lithostratigraphic members that
   record alluvial fan, fluvial, lake margin, and lacustrine deposition
   within a relatively small basin just south of the active Garlock fault
   during the late Miocene to early Pliocene. These sediments experienced
   northwest-southeast contractional deformation during the Pliocene-
   Pleistocene associated with basement-involved reverse faults. Member Two
   of the Horned Toad Formation has yielded 24 taxa of fossil mammals,
   referred to as the Warren Local Fauna, including Cryptotis sp., cf.
   Scapanus, Hypolagus vetus, Hypolagus edensis, ?Spermophilus sp.,
   Prothomomys warrenensis n. gen., n. sp., Perognathus sp., Repomys
   gustelyi, Postcopemys valensis, Peromyscus sp. A, Peromyscus sp. B,
   Jacobsomys dailyi n. sp., Borophagus cf. B. secundus, cf. Agriotherium,
   Machairodus sp. cf. M. coloradensis, Rhynchotherium sp. cf. R. edensis,
   Pliomastodon vexillarius, Dinohippus edensis, Teleoceras sp. cf. T.
   fossiger, cf. Prosthennops, Megatylopus sp. cf. M. matthewi,
   Hemiauchenia vera, Camelidae gen. et. sp. indet., and the antilocaprid
   cf. Sphenophalos. The majority of fossil localities are confined to a 20
   m thick stratigraphic interval within a reversed polarity magnetozone.
   The fauna demonstrates affinity with other late Hemphillian faunas from
   California, Nevada, Nebraska, Texas, and Mexico. The Lawlor Tuff, dated
   elsewhere in California at 4.83 [plus or minus] 0.04 Ma and
   geochemically identified in the Horned Toad Formation, overlies most of
   the fossil mammal localities. Magnetic polarity data are correlated with
   Chrons 3n.3r, 3n.3n, and 3n.2r, suggesting an age of approximately 5.0 -
   4.6 Ma. These constraints indicate an age for the late Hemphillian
   Warren Local Fauna of 4.85 - 5.0 Ma.
C1 May, Steven R.; ExxonMibil Upstream Research, P.O. Box 2189, Houston,
   Texas 77252-2189, USA, USA.
EM steve.may@exxonmobil.com
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1094-8074; 1094-8074
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Documentation; Publications;
   Evolution; Ecology; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA;
   Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Jacobsomys dailyi; Prothomomys warrenensis [California /  / new species]
   [Pliocene /  / ].

   Fossil].

DT Article
TI Cricetid rodents from the Pliocene Panaca Formation, southeastern
   Nevada, USA.
AU Mou, Yun (yunmou2001@yahoo.com) 
SO Palaeontologia Electronica
VL 14
IS 3
PS 14.3.31A, 1-53
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://palaeo-electronica.org/2011_3/index.html
AW http://palaeo-electronica.org/2011_3/19_mou/19_mou.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Very large samples of cricetids were collected from 12 localities in the
   Pliocene Panaca Formation in Meadow Valley, southeastern Nevada. The
   most common cricetids in the Panaca small mammal fauna are Mimomys
   panacaensis, Nevadomys n. gen., and Repomys. Present also are Peromyscus
   and Onychomys. Enamel microstructure of molars of M. panacaensis and
   Nevadomys n. gen. were examined under the scanning electronic
   microscope. Nevadomys n. gen. was probably derived from North American
   Paramicrotoscoptes. The characters of these cricetids, including stage
   of evolution, indicate that the Panaca local fauna represents the early
   Blancan land mammal age.

TI Redescription of Archytas cirphis (Diptera: Tachinidae) and the first
   host record for the Neotropical region.
FT Redescripcion de Archytas cirphis (Diptera: Tachinidae) y primer
   registro del hospedero para la region Neotropical.
AU Gramajo, Maria C. (maricegra@hotmail.com) 
   Mulieri, Pablo R.
SO Revista de la Sociedad Entomologica Argentina
VL 70
IS 1-2
PS 123-128
PD Jan-June 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB The holotype male and a female of Archytas cirphis Curran (Diptera:
   Tachinidae) are redescribed and illustrated. The species is newly
   recorded for Argentina, Paraguay and Peru. Additionally, the host
   Mythimna sp. (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae) is recorded for the first time for
   the Neotropical region.

DT Article
TI Tasmanian Trechinae and Psydrinae (Coleoptera, Carabidae): a taxonomic
   and biogeographic synthesis, with description of new species and
   evaluation of the impact of Quaternary climate changes on evolution of
   the subterranean fauna.
AU Eberhard, Stefan
   Giachino, Pier Mauro (PierMauro.Giachino@regione.piemonte.it) 
SO Subterranean Biology
VL 9
IS 64
PS 1-72
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB This paper provides taxonomic, distributional and ecological data for 59
   species in 17 genera of Trechinae and Psydrinae from Tasmania, and
   describes 18 new species in six existing genera (Pterocyrtus,
   Tasmanorites, Sloanella, Trechistus, Goedetrechus, Tasmanotrechus)
   collected from caves, forest and montane habitats: Pterocyrtus grayi sp.
   nov., P meridionalis sp. nov., Tasmanorites beatricis sp. nov., T
   daccordii sp. nov., T lynceorum sp. nov., T microphthalmus sp. nov.,
   Sloanella gordoni sp. nov., Trechistus gordoni sp. nov., Goedetrechus
   minutus sp. nov., G. rolani sp. nov., G. florentinus sp. nov., G.
   damperi sp. nov., Tasmanotrechus gordoni sp. nov., T alticola sp. nov.,
   T montisfieldi sp. nov., T osbornianus sp. nov., T moorei sp. nov., T
   rolani sp. nov. Forty-one (41) previously described species have been
   re-examined and illustrated with supplementary descriptions. New
   collection records combined with the published literature revealed 196
   records of 83 species in 21 genera, collected from 41 localities
   (including 11 karst areas). Regional-scale survey coverage has been
   patchy and three biogeographic regions stand out as poorly surveyed:
   Flinders, South East, and Northern Midlands. Local-scale survey efforts
   have been intensive at just a few localities, the richest being 18
   species recorded at Cradle Mountain. Seventeen (17) described species of
   Zolini and Trechini are troglobites with distribution ranges restricted
   to individual karst areas. Some karst areas and caves harbour multiple
   congeneric species which differ in their degree of troglomorphic
   specialization suggesting heterochronic colonisations, possibly linked
   to multiple Quaternary glacial / inter-glacial cycles. Palaeo-climatic
   and palaeo-vegetation evidence is examined to test the 'Climatic Relict
   Hypothesis' as a mechanism driving evolution of the subterranean fauna.
   It is proposed that present-day troglobitic Trechinae in Tasmania are
   derived from troglophilic progenitors that colonised subterranean
   habitats from adjacent forest ground litter habitats during Pleistocene
   inter-glacial periods, while retreat of forests during glacial periods
   isolated subterranean populations from surface populations facilitating
   troglogenesis. It is predicted that future collecting efforts will
   reveal many additional new subteranean species, including in non-karstic
   Shallow Subterranean Habitats (SSH).
C1 Giachino, Pier Mauro; Reg Piemonte, Settore Fitosanit Reg, Environm Pk
   Palazzina A2,Via Livorno 60, Turin, I-10144, Italy, Italy.
EM PierMauro.Giachino@regione.piemonte.it

   Meteorology &Atmospheric Sciences

PT J
AN ZOOR14804029813
DT Article
TI Phylogenetic relationships within Maldanidae (Capitellida, Annelida),
   based on morphological characters.
AU De Assis, Jose Eriberto (eri.assis@gmail.com) 
   Christoffersen, Martin Lindsey
SO Systematics and Biodiversity
VL 9
IS 3
PS 233-245
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 13
AB The Maldanidae annelid worms are reviewed and the phylogenetic
   relationships of their subgroups provided, based on Hennigian principles
   and maximum parsimony. Characters were coded as binary and multistate
   (transformation series). We used 33 terminal taxa (species), and 50
   characters. Characters were treated as unordered and of equal weight,
   and analysis was run in TNT. Three equally most-parsimonious trees were
   obtained with heuristic searches, with lengths of 64 steps; CI = 0.95,
   and RI = 0.98. The monophyly of Maldanidae was supported with 100% of
   bootstrap and jackknife values. As a result of our analysis,
   Arenicolidae remains the sister-group of Maldanidae, and both should be
   referred to Maldanomorpha. Maldanidae was supported by the following
   synapomorphies: dorsal prostomium; prostomium keel-shaped and fused to
   peristomium; torus globose behind median chaetigers; median chaetigers
   greatly elongated; number of pre-anal segments reduced. The subfamily
   Bogueinae was not monophyletic; Boguea and Boguella were included within
   Rhodininae. Clymenura, previously included in the Clymenurinae, was
   included within Euclymeninae. The taxa Notoproctinae, Maldaninae,
   Nicomachinae and Euclymeninae were grouped in the Maldanoplaca, a new
   taxon. Eight further new clades have been found, but were not named.
C1 De Assis, Jose Eriberto; Univ Fed Paraiba, Dept Sistemat & Ecol, Joao
   Pessoa, Paraiba, BR-58059900 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM eri.assis@gmail.com
RI Christoffersen, Martin/J-7794-2015
OI Christoffersen, Martin/0000-0001-8108-1938
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1477-2000

   General morphology; Evolution

    / ].

OR Boguea (Polychaeta): [Referred to, Rhodininae from Bogueinae, p. 238]. 
   Boguella (Polychaeta): [Referred to, Rhodininae from Bogueinae, p. 238].
   
   Clymenura (Polychaeta): [Referred to, Euclymeninae from Clymenurinae, p.
   243]. 
   Euclymeninae - Arwidsson 1906 (Polychaeta): [Referred to, New clade
   Maldanoplaca, p. 238]. 
   Maldanidae - Malmgren 1867 (Polychaeta): [Classification, P. 238]. 
   Maldaninae - Malmgren 1867 (Polychaeta): [Referred to, New clade
   Maldanoplaca, p. 238]. 
   Maldanoplaca (Polychaeta): [Taxon nov, New clade, p. 238]. 
   Nicomachinae - Arwidsson 1906 (Polychaeta): [Referred to, New clade
   Maldanoplaca, p. 238]. 
   Notoproctinae - Detinova 1985 (Polychaeta): [Referred to, New clade
   Maldanoplaca, p. 238].

PT J
AN ZOOR14804029814
DT Article
TI Taxonomy, morphology and molecular systematics of a new oligotrich
   ciliate, Williophrya maedai gen. nov., sp nov., with redescriptions of
   Strombidium basimorphum and Pseudotontonia simplicidens (Protozoa,
   Ciliophora, Oligotrichia).
AU Liu, Weiwei
   Yi, Zhenzhen (zyi@scnu.edu.cn) 
   Warren, Alan
   Al-Rasheid, Khaled A.S.
   Al-Farraj, Saleh A.
   Lin, Xiaofeng
   Song, Weibo
SO Systematics and Biodiversity
VL 9
IS 3
PS 247-258
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB The morphology and small subunit rRNA (SSrRNA) gene sequence of a marine
   oligotrich ciliate, Williophrya maedai gen. nov., sp. nov., are
   reported. The new genus Williophrya is characterized by the adoral zone
   with no differentiation of membranelles, and the reduced somatic
   ciliature which comprises a bipartite girdle kinety only. In addition,
   the in vivo morphologies of two other oligotrichs, namely Strombidium
   basimorphum Martin & Montagnes, 1993 and Pseudotontonia simplicidens
   (Lynn & Gilron, 1993) Agatha, 2004, are reported for the first time
   based on Chinese populations. Improved diagnoses of both species are
   supplied. The phylogenetic position of Williophrya maedai is
   investigated based on SSrRNA gene sequence data. These show that: (1)
   Williophrya maedai is most closely related to Strombidium purpureum and
   S. apolatum; (2) Williophrya is assigned to the family Strombidiidae
   although it has some unique morphological features regarding its oral
   and somatic ciliatures.
C1 Yi, Zhenzhen; S China Normal Univ, Coll Life Sci, Guangzhou, Guangdong,
   510631, China, China.
EM zyi@scnu.edu.cn
RI Liu, Weiwei/G-4087-2015; AL-Rasheid, Khaled A S/C-2486-2008
OI AL-Rasheid, Khaled A S/0000-0002-3404-3397
SC Zoology
SN 1477-2000
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description; Marine
   zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Williophrya maedai [North Pacific / China, Guangdong / New species]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Ciliophora, Polyhymenophorea, Spirotrichia, Oligotrichida
OR Pseudotontonia simplicidens - (Lynne & Gilron 1993) (Oligotrichida):
   [Emended diagnosis, P. 251; Redescription, P. 251]. 
   Strombidium basimorphum - Martin & Montagnes 1993 (Oligotrichida):
   [Emended diagnosis, P. 250; Redescription, P. 250]. 
   Williophrya (Oligotrichida): [Gen nov, Of family Strombidiidae, Type
   species Williophrya maedai, p. 248]. 
   Williophrya maedai (Oligotrichida): [Sp nov, China, Guangdong (marine),
   P. 248].

PT J
AN ZOOR14804029816
DT Article
TI Cryptic diversity in Chortis Highland moss salamanders ( Caudata:
   Plethodontidae: Nototriton) revealed using mtDNA barcodes and
   phylogenetics, with a new species from eastern Honduras.
AU Townsend, Josiah H. (josiahh-townsend@gmail.com) 
   Medina-Flores, Melissa
   Murillo, Jorge Luis
   Austin, James D.
SO Systematics and Biodiversity
VL 9
IS 3
PS 275-287
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB The systematic study of Central American moss salamanders has been a
   challenge to researchers due to their cryptic nature and subsequent
   difficulty in sampling. In an effort to elucidate relationships among
   moss salamanders from the Chortis Highlands, we quantified intra- and
   interspecific variation using data from the mitochondrial genes 16S (the
   amphibian barcoding gene), cytochrome b (cyt b; widely used in
   phylogenetic studies of neotropical salamanders), and cytochrome oxidase
   subunit I (COI, the universal metazoan barcoding gene). All three loci
   exhibit a bimodal 'barcoding gap' between ranges of intra-and
   interspecific variation, demonstrating unambiguous species boundaries
   with respect to the mitochondrial loci. A barcoding approach and
   Bayesian and maximum likelihood analyses of the mtDNA dataset revealed
   that the nominal species N. barbouri represents a species complex, with
   two of three populations assigned to this taxon being paraphyletic with
   respect to a sample from the type locality. These data also revealed an
   undescribed species from eastern Honduras, and confirmed the identity of
   allopatric populations of N. lignicola and N. limnospectator. Sequence
   data from cyt b presented an analytical challenge due to a high level of
   substitution saturation at the third codon position for some samples.
   Phylogenetic analyses of the entire dataset including and omitting the
   third position of cyt b resulted in conflicting results with respect to
   the position of the new species and N. tomamorum. Based on the molecular
   data, supplemented with data from external morphology and osteology, we
   formally describe a new species from Sierra de Agalta.
C1 Townsend, Josiah H.; Univ Florida, Sch Nat Resources & Environm,
   Gainesville, FL, 32611, USA, USA.
EM josiahh-townsend@gmail.com
OI Austin, James/0000-0003-0643-8620
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1477-2000
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Biometrics; General morphology;
   Genetics; Evolution; Variation; Land zones; Neotropical region; Central
   America
DE Nototriton [Biometrics / Morphometrics / taxonomic implications]
   [General morphology /  / ] [Genetics / Genetic variation / ] [Molecular
   genetics / mtDNA bar code / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Speciation / Cryptic
   speciation / ] [Biochemical variation /  / ] [Central America / Chortis
   Highlands / distribution]. 
   Nototriton picucha [Honduras /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Caudata,
   Plethodontidae
OR Nototriton (Plethodontidae). 
   Nototriton picucha (Plethodontidae): [Sp nov, Honduras, P. 283].

TI A revision of black flies of the genus Taeniopterna Enderlein, 1925
   (Diptera: Simuliidae) from the fund collection of the Zoological
   Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences.
AU Yankovsky, A.V. (alekyank@zin.ru) 
SO Trudy Zoologicheskogo Instituta
VL 315
IS 4
PS 412-440
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB As a result of the examination of the fund collection of black flies
   (Diptera: Simuliidae) of the Zoological Institute of the Russian Academy
   of Sciences, a detailed re-descriptions and original drawings of 12
   species (of 13 known in the world fauna) of the genus Taeniopterna
   Enderlein, 1925 (all known Palaearctic species of this genus) are given,
   2 species are described as a new species, pupa of 1 species, male and
   female of 1 species are described for the first time, 1 former
   subspecies is treated as the separate species. Key to all 13 species of
   the genus Taeniopterna is provided.

DT Article
TI Four new species of oribatid mites (Acari: Oribatida) from Vietnam.
AU Ermilov, S.G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Anichkin, A.E.
SO Zoosystematica Rossica
VL 20
IS 2
PS 200-215
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Four new species of oribatid mites, Unguizetes cattienensis sp. nov.
   (Mochlozetidae), Gigantoppia zryanini sp. nov. (Granuloppiidae),
   Caucasiozetes frankeae sp. nov. (Microzetidae) and Otocepheus
   (Acrotocepheus) vietnamicus sp. nov. (Otocepheidae) from forest soil,
   litter and decaying wood of Cat Tien National Park in southern Vietnam
   are described. The representative of the genus Gigantoppia as well as
   Unguizetes sphaerula is recorded for the first time in Vietnam, and the
   genus Caucasiozetes is firstly recorded in the Oriental Region. A new
   generic diagnosis of Caucasiozetes is presented, and an identification
   key to the Vietnamese species of Otocepheus (Acrotocepheus) is
   presented.
C1 Ermilov, S.G.; Nizhniy Novgorod Referral Ctr, Fed Serv Vet &
   Phytosanitary Inspect, 97 Gagarina Prospect, Nizhniy Novgorod, 603107,
   Russia, Russia.

AB A new cranefly species, Tipula (Savtshenkia) anadyrensis sp. nov. from
   the northern Far East, is described and illustrated. The species belongs
   to the subnodicornis group and is close to T. postposita Riedel, 1919.
   The female of the new species has short wings.

U1 0
U2 1
AB During two visits to the Red Sea Mountains in the Eastern Desert of
   Egypt, in March and Nov-December 2010, 46 bird species were identified.
   Predators and scavengers, small bush insectivores and small ground
   insectivores were the guilds with the more numerous species in the
   mountain range. Compared to other saharans massifs at the same latitude
   (e. g. Mauritanian Adrar and Hoggar), the Red Sea Montains support
   species with a restricted distribution in the Sahara, both palearctic
   (Bearded Vulture, Bonelli Eagle), and "sahara-sindian" (Hume's Owl,
   Hooded Wheater...) breeding species and oriental migrants following the
   Red Sea corridor.
C1 Clouet, Michel; 43 rue Monplaisir, F-31400 Toulouse, France, France.
EM dr.clouet@wanadoo.fr
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0002-4619
BD Ecology; Habitat; Terrestrial habitat; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Africa
DE Aves [Trophic structure /  / ] [Mountain habitat /  / faunal list]
   [Egypt / East, Red Sea Mountains / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata
OR Aves (Vertebrata). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14801002296
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14801003260
DT Article
TI First Report of Papaya Mealybug Paracoccus marginatus (Hemiptera:
   Pseudococcidae) from Malaysia.
AU Mastoi, M.I.
   Nur Azura, A. (nur_azura@putra.upm.edu.my) 
   Muhammad, R.
   Idris, A.B.
   Ibrahim, Y.
SO Australian Journal of Basic and Applied Sciences
VL 5
IS 7
PS 1247-1250
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Paracoccus marginatus, Williams and Granara de Willink 1992 (Hemiptera:
   Pseudococcidae) commonly known as papaya mealybug (PMb) is reported for
   the first time in Malaysia on papaya, cassava, eggplant, Jatropha and
   hibiscus plants. Four species of chalcidoid parasitoids were observed
   parasitizing the PMb. Acerophagus papayae was the major parasitoid of
   PMb. Two common predators namely Apertochrysa sp. and Cryptolaemus
   montouzieri were also found feeding on PMb.
C1 Nur Azura, A.; Dept. of Plant Protection, Faculty of Agriculture,
   Universiti Putra Malaysia, 43400 UPM Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia,
   Malaysia.
EM nur_azura@putra.upm.edu.my
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Entomology; Nutrition &Dietetics; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology
SN 1991-8178
BD Nutrition; Diet; Prey; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites;
   Insect parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Ecology; Predators; Land zones;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Acerophagus papayae; Chalcidoidea [Hemipteran hosts / Paracoccus
   marginatus / New record] [Malaysia / Negeri Sembilan, Perak & Selangor /
   ]. 
   Apertochrysa; Cryptolaemus montouzieri [Insect prey / Paracoccus
   marginatus (Hemiptera) / New record] [Malaysia / Negeri Sembilan, Perak
   & Selangor / ]. 
   Paracoccus marginatus [Hymenopteran parasites / Acerophagus papayae /
   New record] [ / Chalcidoidea / ] [Plant hosts / Cassava, eggplant,
   hibiscus, Jatropha & papaya / prevalence; natural enemy survey] [Insect
   predators / Apertochrysa (Neuroptera) / ] [ / Cryptolaemus montouzieri
   (Coleoptera) / ] [Malaysia / Negeri Sembilan, Perak & Selangor / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs

   Coccinellidae, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Sternorrhyncha, Coccoidea,
   Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia, Chalcidoidea, Encyrtidae, Neuroptera
OR Cryptolaemus montouzieri (Coccinellidae): [Predator; New record]. 
   Paracoccus marginatus (Coccoidea): [Host; New record]. 
   Chalcidoidea (Terebrantia): [Parasite; New record].

DT Article
TI Eupteryx cytinsularis, a new specie of the melissae group (Rhynchota
   Auchenorrhyncha cicadellidae) from Sicily, Sardinia and Corsica.
AU Guglielmino, Adalgisa (guglielm@unitus.it) 
   Lauterer, Pavel
   Bueckle, Christoph
SO Bulletin of Insectology
VL 64
IS 1
PS 23-26
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eupteryx cytinsularis sp. nov. (Rhynchota Auchenorrhyncha Cicadellidae
   Typhlocybinae), closely related to Eupteryx andalusiaca Ferrari and
   Eupteryx rostrata Ribaut, is described from Sicily, Sardinia and
   Corsica. Its position within the genus Eupteryx is discussed. In
   Sardinia the new species was collected on Cytisus villosus Pourret
   (Fabaceae).
C1 Guglielmino, Adalgisa; Dipartimento di Protezione delle Piante,
   Universita della Tuscia, Via S. Camillo de Lellis, 01100 Viterbo, Italy,
   Italy.

DT Article
TI A record of Metriorrhynchus beetles (Coleoptera: Lycidae) feeding on the
   flowers of the introduced tree, Acer buergerianum Miquel (Aceraceae) in
   New South Wales, Australia.
AU Hawkeswood, Trevor J.
SO Calodema
VL 179
PS 1-3
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A record is provided herein of a Metriorrhynchus sp. (probably M.
   rhipidius Macleay)(Coleoptera: Lycidae) feeding on open flowers of the
   introduced tree, Acer buergerianum Miq. (Aceraceae). This is the first
   record of a Metriorrhynchus species feeding on an introduced plant
   (tree) species as well as the first record of an Australian beetle
   feeding on flowers of A. buergerianum.
C1 Hawkeswood, Trevor J.; PO Box 842, Richmond, New South Wales 2753,
   Australia, Australia.
SC Nutrition &Dietetics; Zoology
SN 1448-5532

   introduced plant] [New South Wales / Richmond / ].

   Lycidae
OR Metriorrhynchus (Lycidae): [New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR14801000715
DT Article
TI Ciliophora, Phyllopharyngea, Discophryidae, Setodiscophrya steinii
   (Claparede and Lachmann, 1859): Range extension and first record from
   Italy.
AU Marino-Perez, Ricardo (pselliopus@yahoo.com.mx) 
   Mayen-Estrada, Rosaura
   Fontana, Paolo
SO Check List
VL 7
IS 4
PS 389-390
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.checklist.org.br/archive?vol=7&num=4
AW http://www.checklist.org.br/getpdf?NGD070-11
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Setodiscophrya Jankowski, 1981 has been previously recorded
   only from Germany, France, Russia, Ukraine and Japan. We provide the new
   record of Setodiscophrya steinii (Claparede and Lachmann, 1859) as an
   ectosymbiont of Ochthebius sp., in the province of Basilicata, Italy
   which represents the first record of the genus Setodiscophrya for Italy
   and the first worldwide record of S. steinii being associated to the
   coleopteran family Hydraenidae (Ochthebius sp.). The rang distribution
   of S. steinii is expanded 900 km southwards.
C1 Marino-Perez, Ricardo; Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, Facultad
   de Ciencias, Departamento de biologia Comparada, Laboratorio de
   Protozoologia, Circulto Exterior s/n, Ciudad Universitaria, 04510
   Mexico, DF, Mexico, Mexico.
EM pselliopus@yahoo.com.mx
RI ; Marino-Perez, Ricardo/F-3488-2019
OI Fontana, Paolo/0000-0001-9710-759X; Marino-Perez,
   Ricardo/0000-0002-0566-1372

SN 1809-127X
BD Associations; Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Europe
DE Ochthebius [Commensalism / Setodiscophrya steinii (Protozoa) / New
   record; ectosymbiont] [Italy /  / Protozoan commensals]. 
   Setodiscophrya [Zoogeography /  / New record] [Italy /  / ]. 
   Setodiscophrya steinii [Commensalism / Ochthebius (Coleoptera) / New
   record; ectosymbiosis] [Italy /  / Coleopteran commensals]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates; Protozoans

   Hydraenidae, Protozoa, Ciliophora, Kinetofragminophorea, Suctoria
OR Ochthebius (Hydraenidae): [New record]. 
   Setodiscophrya (Suctoria): [New record]. 
   Setodiscophrya steinii (Suctoria): [New record].

   Pseudotealliocaris holthuisi (Pygocephalomorpha): [Sp nov, Kentucky,
   Carboniferous, P. 345; Fossil]. 
   Tealliocarididae (Pygocephalomorpha): [Fossil; New record].
